The purpose of this private member's bill is to include the 10 and 11 year old age group as young persons governed by the Young Offenders Act.
At present that act does not apply to anyone less than 12 years of age. Second, it is to lower the age of
culpability in the Criminal Code from 12 years to 10 years.
The reason for these proposed changes is that the 10 and 11 year old group are increasingly turning up as perpetrators of assaults causing bodily harm, sexual assaults, threats, extortion and drug couriers, especially in large urban areas.
Under the current law police are unable to charge or arrest young offenders in this 10 and 11 year old age group. This law would rectify this problem for the 10 and 11 year old age group.

speakeroldname: Hon. Barbara McDougall (Secretary of State for External Affairs) moved
speakerposition: Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
that Bill C-53, an act to provide for the imposition of special economic measures, be read the second time and referred to Legislative Committee E.
She said: Madam Speaker, I am very pleased to lead off the debate today on Bill C-53, an act to provide for the imposition of special economic measures.
Now that the cold war is over, we are living in a period of unprecedented opportunity to enhance international peace and security. Countries are rethinking the way they have conducted international relations for the past 45 years. The international community is looking for new and effective ways to maintain international peace and security with minimal recourse to military force.
The responses of the United Nations and the Organization of American States to the gulf and Haitian crises have highlighted the new opportunities for collective measures to suppress acts of aggression and respond to internationally unacceptable behaviour.
It is in this context that the government has introduced Bill C-53, an act to provide for the imposition of special economic measures.
The purpose of Bill C-53 is to enable Canada to impose a broad range of economic sanctions against a state or part of a state whose actions pose a serious threat to international peace or security or fail to conform to commonly accepted standards of behaviour.
The act will improve Canada's ability to join other states promptly and effectively in the application of economic sanctions.

February 20,1992
Government Orders

The application of economic sanctions will remain an exceptional measure, but it is an essential foreign policy instrument. There are occasions when other peaceful means such as diplomatic representations, public condemnations, various demarches will not bring a delinquent state or a rogue regime to modify its behaviour.
In these circumstances the ability to join promptly in the application of multilateral economic sanctions is both valuable and necessary. The use of economic sanctions, of course, is not new to Canadian foreign policy. On a number of occasions over the past 25 years, Canada has joined like-minded states in resorting to economic sanctions for one reason or another.

For example, comprehensive sanctions were applied against Rhodesia in 1968 and against Iraq in 1990. The United Nations imposed an arms embargo against South Africa in 1977 and more extensive economic measures were applied in 1985 and 1986.
Limited sanctions were applied against Iran and the Soviet Union in 1980, Poland and Argentina in 1982, Libya in 1986 and Haiti in 1991.

These instances have revealed that our domestic authority to impose sanctions is not appropriate to the current situation. We have seen, for example, that disagreement among the permanent members of the UN Security Council regularly made it impossible to use the United Nations Act to apply sanctions. The Export and Import Permits Act only permits restrictions on trade and goods. Moreover, the requirement for an intergovernmental arrangement or commitment in order to control imports for foreign policy reasons has occasionally made use of that act cumbersome and difficult.
The passage of the special legislation such as the Iran Economic Sanctions Act takes time. Opportunities to effectively influence the outcome of a crisis can thus be lost. Other legislation such as the Emergencies Act was never intended for the application of international economic sanctions and is in fact of very little use.
Measures that are within the discretion of the government can be useful in some circumstances, but they would likely be neither a sufficient nor an appropriate response to the unacceptable behaviour of another state.
In the past we have been able to make do with a limited ability to impose international economic sanctions, but that is no longer the case. The world has changed. Not only has the end of the cold war created these new opportunities for concerted international action that Canada and other countries must seize, the character of international economic relations and the structure of economic transactions have also changed. In the past, relatively effective sanctions could be applied by merely controlling trade in goods.
Today, however, trade in services accounts for an ever larger part of international transactions. In addition, in an age of electronic banking huge sums of money and other assets can be moved from one country to another almost instantaneously. Bill C-53 addresses these new developments and in its provision for controlling trade and technology, for example, a very important element in today's international exchanges, it tries to anticipate others yet to come.
When I speak of these changes I am referring to situations that are very real. After the coup d'etat in Haiti, the ad hoc meeting of ministers of foreign affairs of the Organization of American States urged OAS member states to embargo trade with Haiti and to freeze Haitian state assets. Canada, however, found itself with only limited authority to block financial transactions involving Haiti and to freeze Haitian state assets in Canada. Had the special economic measures act been in force when the coup took place, Canada would have been better placed to respond quickly and effectively to the OAS request. Indeed, Canada had led the OAS in calling for strong economic measures against Haiti and it therefore is of course doubly important that we are in a position to follow through.
With the legislation in place, we will be able to respond better. Embargoes are not always easy to apply. That said, we are concerned that some OAS members, including the United States, apparently appear to be backing away from giving full effect to the OAS resolutions. That reluctance can undermine the effectiveness of sanctions, and it makes it difficult for countries like Canada to sustain the sanctions when others are not sharing the burden. We want to implement measures that will contribute to the return of constitutional government in Haiti. We urge our fellow members to do likewise, as well as other countries. This action was a breakthrough for the Organization of American States
February 20, 1992

and in our view it is very important that we act as member states in concert.
I have spoken about why Canada needs the special economic measures act. Now I want to talk about the bill itself. This is enabling legislation. It will allow but not require the government to apply international economic sanctions. Bill C-53 signals no intention to apply sanctions either more or less frequently than we have in the past. Canadian decisions to use sanctions will be guided by established policies and the need for sanctions will be dictated by developments in international relations. I can, however, assure you that Canada will continue to work hard with the objective of ensuring that sanctions will be called for only on rare occasions. When the government does decide to apply sanctions, the act will give it the flexibility to choose those measures which are best suited for the situation at hand.

The essence of the bill is found in section 4, which describes the conditions for the application of sanctions and the types of measures that may be applied. Sanctions may be applied if the Governor in Council determines that a grave breach of international peace and security has occurred and has resulted or is likely to result in a serious international crisis. Sanctions may also be applied in response to a decision, resolution or recommendation of an international organization or association of states of which Canada is a member, calling for the application of sanctions.
Under the act the government will be able to seize or sequeseter the property held in Canada by the state that is subject to sanctions or by persons associated with it.

The government will also be able to make orders or regulations restricting or prohibiting a variety of activities such as trade in goods and services, the execution of financial and commercial transactions, the transfer of technology and the operation of air and maritime links.
Bill C-53 is fully consistent with long established Canadian foreign policy that has always treated the application of international economic sanctions as a very
Government Orders
serious and exceptional measure. In applying economic sanctions Canadian governments have been guided by three principles. Canada has sought a broad international agreement on the necessity and usefulness of sanctions. Canada has insisted that the burden of sanctions be shared among the countries imposing them and Canada has made every effort to avoid placing Canadian business and workers at a disadvantage in relation to its foreign competitors.
Nothing in this bill requires departure from these longstanding principles of Canadian foreign policy and they will indeed continue to guide us. Every situation in which sanctions will be imposed, of course, will be different.
To be effective, international economic sanctions should be used in pursuit of very precisely and clearly defined objectives. Sanctions measures must be carefully conceived because those that would be effective in one set of circumstances may be totally inappropriate, perhaps even costly in another.
Decisions to impose economic sanctions will involve a complex balancing of many considerations. The kinds of measures to be taken, their likely effectiveness and the potential cost to Canadians will need to be addressed every time a proposal is made to impose sanctions.
Consequently Bill C-53 does not dictate the policy considerations that would determine whether or not to apply sanctions in any particular situation, nor does it dictate the types of measures to be used when the government decides to apply sanctions.
The flexibility that must be granted to the government in Bill C-53 warrants parliamentary scrutiny. In applying sanctions as the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait demonstrated, the government must be able to act quickly.
However, once the government has acted every order and regulation made in application for sanctions must be laid before each House of Parliament within five sitting days of its making. If 50 members or 20 senators move that any order or regulation be revoked, the motion must be debated and brought to a vote.

February 20, 1992
Government Orders
When Canada applies economic sanctions, every effort must be made to minimize the costs to Canada's business community and to Canada's workers.

For instance, where possible, restrictions should be applied prospectively, thereby permitting the execution of existing contracts. Where costs to Canadians are unavoidable, government programs might be adapted to assist those in Canada who bear the burden. This was done in 1980 when the existing grain price support programs were used to relieve farmers from depressed cereal prices that resulted from Canadian participation in the grain embargo against the Soviet Union. When Canada has applied economic sanctions, direct compensation has seldom been requested. Nonetheless, we do not exclude the possibility that in some future circumstances the government might want to consider the need for a program of compensation for Canadians and persons in Canada adversely affected by the application of economic sanctions. Section 6 of the bill provides for that eventuality.

This bill is timely legislation that responds to changes in international circumstances. It reflects changes in the character of international business.
The special economic measures act will fit within longstanding Canadian policy that seeks multilateral solutions to international problems. It will be a valuable addition to the peaceful options available to the government to respond to threats to international peace and security.
I hope that all hon. members will see the value of this important legislation and allow for quick passage so that additional options can be considered for addressing effectively the Haitian situation in particular. It is of most immediate concern, but of course there will be others in the future.

Madam Speaker, there is some irony in that just about a year ago this House was deeply engaged in a major debate about the Gulf War.
Members of the opposition were trying to put the best case forward to the government about the utility and effectiveness of economic sanctions. They were being
treated with total indifference and sometimes arrogance saying that sanctions had no role to play.
It was said that sanctions were useless and were not being effective in that case. One year later, we are now dealing with a bill that centres on the importance and effectiveness of economic sanctions.
It certainly shows that, if nothing else is true, the government has been able to understand the weakness of its ways.
I would like to recall that at that time we said that there were choices and there were options.
We said that this Parliament should have far more responsibility for the setting of standards by which we determine our actions internationally with respect to the democratic interests of this country. Those were being spumed and those were being treated with total and complete impunity.
We are now seized of a bill that we hope will improve upon that. One can at least be thankful that a few lessons were learned as a consequence of that terrible tragedy.
Of course, not all lessons were learned because what we are still faced with is the enormous consequences of a war that spent close to 80 billion scarce dollars. It burned it up at a rate of something like $60 million an hour, and what are the results?
The results are mass starvation in Iraq, continuation of a despotic regime, environmental despoilment, the continuing arms trade in the Middle East, in fact an escalating arms trade in the Middle East. Also, close to three-quarters of a million refugees are scattered throughout the Middle East. A number of countries are impoverished.
Because of a lack of patience, because of a lack of interest or concern about the utility and effectiveness of the use of economic sanctions, we are paying a very deep, steep price even today for that imprudence and lack of caution and jingoism that so terribly seized the Government of Canada, as it did many other governments at that time.
I would say at the outset that we welcome this legislation. It may provide a more important and useful tool for the government. It may in the future be prepared to exercise that option without resorting so quickly and ferociously to the use of force as the first
February 20, 1992

Government Orders
resort, rather than the last resort, in trying to deal with the problem of international conflict and aggression.
It does not mean to say, however, that economic sanctions by themselves are sufficient or should not go unexamined. The minister mentioned in her opening address the application of sanctions to Haiti. Well, let us just stop for a moment and ask what is happening there.
Again, Canada along with other countries was quick to rush to the press conferences to announce a whole series of strictures against the dictatorship that took over in Haiti.
But now Haitian refugees are being sent back and are having to return a second time to political persecution. I have seen no statement from the Minister of External Affairs or from the Prime Minister of Canada about how we intend to help many of those refugees who are there as a direct consequence of the actions being taken.
There is no question that economic sanctions have their consequences, have their results.
It is a negligence in responsibility that we undertake in participating in a multilateral action properly designed to force an end to a dictatorship in a country like Haiti that we take no responsibility, no interest whatsoever in the victims of that action.
My colleague from Broadview-Greenwood will speak later about the efforts he has been making to try to get foodstuffs and humanitarian supplies into Iraq for the children there.
We now have a series of reports. Once again we find, as I discovered on my visit to the United Nations last week, that we are concentrating on enforcement and pressure.
At the same time we are ignoring and forgetting that there is always another side to the equation. That side of the equation includes the people who suffer, the people who pay the price, the individuals, the men and women and particularly the children who suffer the results of that.
The bill itself gives us an important opportunity to honestly examine what it is about-a sanctions policy.
I was disturbed to hear the minister when she said that she treats the legislation purely in mechanical terms, not in policy terms.
It is important for Canada to have policies in these areas. It is important for the Canadian people to understand what the policy of the Government of Canada will be when it becomes engaged in major international actions. It is crucial that we understand what objectives and goals and values motivate and seize this kind of action.
It is not simply a mechanical matter of turning over and responding. It is a question of making choices and judgments and engaging in a proper public debate as to what they require.
It is no wonder that Canadians are confused today about what is our position in the new world order, that we will apply sanctions to one country but not to another.
Look what happened in Yugoslavia where we watched for months upon months the escalation, suffering, damage, and terrible tragedy. Yet western countries were not prepared. Maybe we did not have the means.
It looked once again as if there was a double standard being applied, that we were beginning to say that we will apply enforcement action in one place and not in another depending on what the politics dictate.
It may be that there are realistic reasons for doing that, but they should be spelled out. There should be a much stronger effort to engage Canadians in this kind of debate and discussion.
If we are going to be called upon, as I believe we will be, for a much broader and more active role in maintaining collective peace and security, then it can only be done if there is support from the public. They must understand what is being done. They must be engaged in the debate.
It should not be a decision made behind closed doors in a cabinet room, remote and separated from what it is Canadians believe should take the place.
If we are going to be sending peacekeepers to one area and impose sanctions in another, that has to be part of a judgment made by the people. This is done through their parliamentary system where there is a serious and

February 20, 1992
Government Orders
considerate effort to share information, where there is a realistic opportunity to judge the impact of those actions.
I can recall what took place during the debates in this House during the gulf war when we constantly said to the predecessor to the present minister for external affairs: "Tfell us why sanctions are not working, why it is necessary right now to engage in military action".
There was never any mechanism, no real effort to provide that information. There was no evidence. There was no analysis. There were no judgments to say: "Here is why we think economic sanctions as an instrument will not work and therefore we are going to be forced into more serious military engagement".
I ask whether there is anything in Bill C-53 that will correct that, that will require the government to be accountable to Parliament for how the sanctions are working, who is being affected and whether the sanctions are having the desired result.
I suggest that there is nothing in the bill that will ensure the continual observation, monitoring and accountability of this very important and serious international engagement the minister is proposing that Canadians undertake.
Let us be honest. There is no real parliamentary role in this. The measures built into this bill are farcical.
There is nothing to say what happens if Parliament is in a summer recess, as we were during the time of the gulf war, and is not called back for three months. Where is the opportunity in this bill to correct that serious omission of fundamental parliamentary responsibility?
There is nothing in the bill that would require Parliament to be immediately recalled so that a proper debate could be held and members of Parliament on behalf of their constituents could raise questions and determine what the severity of the situation would be. No, this would be a decision taken on high through executive decision and Parliament would be hoeing its garden or doing whatever.
Similarly in the bill there is no capacity for Parliament, again representing the people of Canada, to determine when sanctions are working or when they should be withdrawn or when they should be changed. Sanctions are not some kind of iceberg that sits there. They have to
be constantly monitored. Businesses are being put at financial risk, there are enormous consequences in terms of the countries in which sanctions are being employed, and the only provision we have is that 50 MPs get up and say: "We do not want sanctions". Where is the flexibility in that? It is not a question of black or white, but it is a question of responsibility, accountability, information sharing, reporting and proper debate.
I can say to the House that we will be making every effort to improve this bill, to substantially improve the position of Parliament in its role of ensuring that such an important international commitment as the imposition of a sanctions program is subject to parliamentary assessment, judgment and accountability.
I hope the minister will be in agreement with those measures. We are primarily arguing about the fact that we cannot go around the world preaching democracy if we are not prepared to acknowledge it at home. How can we be lecturing other countries about the importance of building democratic institutions if we ignore our own institutions on such a crucial issue as war and peace or major international engagement?
One of the reasons we will be prepared to give quick passage to the bill is so that we can bring it to committee as quickly as possible and prepare a number of amendments that we believe will substantially improve the bill in terms of parliamentary role.
I might as well raise another set of concerns about Bill C-53, that is the triggering of its application. The minister has outlined that it would be triggered by requests from international organizations where there is a judgment about peace and security. I want to pose some questions of the minister. What happens to cases where there are severe violations of human rights?
We see cases now in East Timor and other places around the world where it may be important that the economic tool be used to live up to the principle that the minister and the Prime Minister have established of connecting human rights to economic aid. It is surprising that there is an omission in this bill, that there is not the same kind of flexibility being shown in applying some enforcement action for countries which are not prepared to listen to international standards and adhere to international standards of human rights.
February 20, 1992

Similarly it may be important to consider whether in this bill we should also consider a criterion of environmental pollution and degradation. We saw a case just a year or so ago when the U.S. Congress applied a form of economic sanctions on tuna fishing against Mexico. It had the desired result, by the way, of stopping a kind of raping of the tuna fleet.
In the last three or four days in this House we have had major debate about what is happening outside the 200-mile limit in our own Grand Banks area. It may be important that we at least keep in the arsenal-and I am not saying for it to be used in a capricious way-the possibility of using economic tools or weapons to respond to countries which take no responsibility for ravaging the ocean's environment, or other environments for that matter. It may be important to consider additional criteria under which this bill can be applied.
It is also important, just as a third area where I think improvement and additions are required, in the field of compensation. As I read the bill we talk about the right to make application for compensation. There is nothing in the bill that says the government has to respond in any tangible way. To make sanctions an effective instrument, as we have seen in past experiences there has to be a commitment by which affected individuals or businesses have a clear mechanism, by which they have some security that their own interests will not be again victimized, and by which they are not the only ones paying the penalty.
In saying all that, it is important to put this bill in perspective. It is really only one of the top most rungs of the international ladder that we have to climb if we are to try to recreate a new international regime or environment.
An important paper delivered at the UN symposium that our party sponsored in Vancouver in October was by Professor Edwin Smith, an international lawyer. It dealt specifically with the question of economic sanctions. He pointed out something which I think would be of interest to members, that under article VII there is only one reference to how economic sanctions should be applied. He pointed out in his paper, if I can quote: "After 45 years we have not had one single military operation that followed the procedures laid out by the charter, but we
Government Orders
have had many instances of the application of economic sanctions". He also said: "It would be unfortunate if these economic measures were left to ad hoc procedures that did not benefit from the preservation of institutional memory". He went on to talk about the necessity for the United Nations, if it is to become the major source of decision making in these areas, to enunciate clearly how, where and by what means these decisions will be made.
The interview the Leader of the Opposition and I had with the Secretary-General last week was interesting. It was pointed out that they are now busily preparing a paper to be tabled with the Security Council on July 1 on a whole new set of means of collective security instruments that will be required by the UN.
I find surprising that here we are in the middle of February and there does not seem at this point to be any initiative on the part of the Canadian government to make proposals as to what that paper should include. This may be one of the most important set of recommendations emerging in building the architecture for a new international peace and security system through the UN, and Canada, which is one of the countries that has been called upon in many instances to supply peacekeeping forces or other responses, does not seem to be part of the action. We are not engaging either in this Parliament or anywhere else in serious debate about what we would like the new architecture to be at the United Nations.
What should be the role of the Secretary-General? Should there be a very specific sanctions group, peacekeeping group in the apparatus of the United Nations, so that a wider range of countries than simply those on the Security Council has an opportunity to be involved in the decision making, the implementation and the accountability?
Surely, as a specific interest of Canadians, we are about to send close to 1,000 peacekeepers to Yugoslavia and we are still not clear in this day and age as to the responsibilities and accountabilities of those who decide on these issues.
I believe there will be a meeting of the peacekeeping committee beginning in the first week of April which Canada will chair. It would seem to me that is an important opportunity for us to put forward a series of proposals on peacemaking, on how the Secretary-General may have offices in different parts of the world to

February 20,1992
Government Orders
provide preventative diplomacy, on how there could be a new information sharing system at the UN, and on how we could be establishing a standby peacekeeping force that could implement sanctions or other areas. There is a wide range of initiatives that I believe Canadians are interested in.
When we held the symposium the response was incredible. People wanted to come. They wanted to discuss and debate this matter, but we have not yet given them an opportunity in the House to provide that kind of involvement. If there should be any lesson that is clear from the gulf war and since then, it is that sanctions and the military should be the last resorts and not the first resort.
It may be that it would have been a more useful initiative by the minister to present a resolution in this House prior to this bill on a peacemaking policy for Canada, the kind of things that we would like the Canadian government to be proposing at the UN and at the OAS in terms of new instruments, procedures and processes for looking at the diplomatic efforts and multilateral action for determining how we can prevent conflict, offset aggression and provide deterrence to the kind of things that happened in the gulf war as opposed to simply responding to them after they happen.
I would use this opportunity, if I might, to urge the minister to do that. I think Canadians are interested. They want to become involved in that kind of debate. I think it is a long-standing tradition of our foreign policy that Canadians become committed and feel a responsibility to multilateral action.
Surely, if the gulf war has taught us anything, it is that the mechanics and the institutions lack a great deal. They need to be modernized, improved and renovated to bring them up to the kind of conditions we now face. We are lagging behind in our capacity to make peace in this world internationally, multilaterally and domestically.
I cannot think of a more profound, serious debate that could take place in this House of Commons. Perhaps the government is prepared to come forward and present its ideas and its proposals and to have serious debate about where we should go in this area before the Secretary-General tables his report on July 1, before decisions are made, and before the security council is seized of this issue.
I would say in summation that the bill itself is a useful measure. It is a beginning but it certainly misses one of the critical criteria in this new age the minister talked about, in this new environment where peace and security may be in our grasp. It will only happen if Canadians understand what their responsibilities and obligations are. They have to feel that they are part of making these decisions. I would strongly urge all members of the House to support the amendments and measures we will be promoting to ensure that on a crucial issue such as economic sanctions Canadians have a role to play, that they have a voice that will be heard, and that they will be part of a decision that is committing themselves and their country to important initiatives overseas.
We would ask this House to support a bill that is substantially amended in the interests of a democratic foreign policy.

Mr. Speaker, we support this bill. In the circumstances it is very important for the government to have the authority to impose economic sanctions as an alternative to war.

We support this bill. We believe it to be a very important bill and one which should have the support of all members of this House as it goes through the parliamentary process.
The bill provides the government with the necessary ability to move very quickly in imposing economic sanctions during an appropriate international crisis. As was argued during the time of the gulf war, we see sanctions as an important alternative to the use of military force in solving international problems.
The government has introduced this bill because as it found during the gulf war it did not have an effective set of legislative authority to impose sanctions as required under UN resolutions or by other appropriate government policy.
All sides in this House during the gulf war supported the use of economic sanctions. We can do nothing else but support the government in reorganizing and making more effective the mechanisms for dealing with economic sanctions when they are required. The legislation would allow the government to freeze the assets of foreign states which offend international law, would

prohibit or restrict the import and export of goods and services to an offending state and other financial and commercial transactions as well as air and sea links. It also can restrict the activities of Canadians outside Canada when an organization or association of states calls for such measures. This is an important set of powers for the government in exercising international policy in this country.
The spokesperson for the Liberal Party has outlined some of his concerns with this bill. Frankly, at this stage we do not share some of those concerns. We certainly agree that Parliament needs to be consulted on every opportunity, but we note with interest that the bill does provide for consultation with Parliament by the provision under clause 7 for tabling of orders and regulations made under the bill within five sitting days of the House after they have been made and the filing of a motion on it and an opportunity for Parliament to debate it. It may well be that these provisions should be improved. That is what the committee process will be for and we will be addressing that.
We, of course, also agree with the general proposition that Parliament should be consulted in the process of decision-making wherever possible. In the case of economic sanctions, we do concede to the government the necessary authority to move as quickly as possible. We would not want any consultative process with Parliament to inhibit a government's opportunity to move as fast as possible when the circumstances require it. We will work that one out in committee and hopefully we can improve the bill there.
We have two or three other concerns which are relatively minor when compared with the over-all importance of this bill and we will discuss them when we get to committee. Perhaps I could simply flag them at this stage. The first has to do with a concern that the authority to the government to seize property of a national of a foreign state who does not ordinarily reside in Canada may impinge upon the rights of refugees and others who are legitimately here. We want to make sure that there is a very clear commitment from the government in the legislation, as part of the legislation, to
Government Orders
ensure that appropriate rights of those who are resident in Canada are not infringed by the exercise of the government's authority here.
As well, there may be a concern and a need to have some mechanism for compensation to Canadian individuals or businesses adversely affected by economic sanctions imposed. Obviously in many cases that ought not to be required, but there may be appropriate cases where it is. We want the legislative committee to look at that.
Finally, we want to make sure that non-governmental organizations have some mechanism to continue to operate, again in appropriate circumstances, in a country which is the subject of sanctions under this legislation. There may be many in particular situations under which that is required and we want to make sure that is permitted and not inhibited by the legislation.
Having said that, let me now just turn to a brief discussion of the general bill itself and the reasons for our taking the position that we do in this particular case. International organizations and nations have a range of possible responses to breaches of international law under the United Nations charter. Governments and states can condemn, can call in ambassadors, can impose a series of steps short of actually putting serious hurtful pressure on a particular country. When those options do not work, it becomes necessary from time to time for the international community to act much more effectively. The two particular options which are often available are military sanctions-military action, military force-on the one hand or economic sanctions on the other.
As we have seen throughout history, frequently there are occasions when economic sanctions are far more effective and far more important than military sanctions and military action. There is a tendency, however, when governments have come equipped with large military forces for there often to be too quick a response by the use of military force than the more patient response that is needed in the use of economic sanctions.
When we look back on history we see that economic sanctions have frequently been very effective. This debate gives us an opportunity to reflect on that at a time that we are not dealing with a major and immediate crisis, although we have a number of important interna-

tional issues on the table at this stage. I will get to those in a minute.
In a study which was published during the time of the gulf war and reported in a number of newspapers, including the New York Times, the Toronto Globe and Mail and Toronto Star, by Garry C. Hufbauer and Kimberly A. Elliott, two American specialists in the field, it was noted that in 1935-36 sanctions were applied by the League of Nations against Mussolini for his invasion of Ethiopia. The international community was then trying to force Italy to withdraw from Ethiopia.
In subsequent years that particular case has often been held up as a failure of sanctions. Yet a closer examination shows that sanctions were within a week of forcing Mussolini to back out of Ethiopia and he so confessed to Hitler at some subsequent point. We have an early example in the thirties of sanctions coming very close to working. If the international community had stuck to its position, we might have had a significant change in history during that period.
We have had the example in the early eighties of sanctions against Poland effectively changing the political decisions of that government so as to ease repression, to make economic changes which eventually triggered the changes that we see in Poland and in eastern Europe today.
Governments and states have used economic sanctions against dictators over the years: Trujillo in the Dominican Republic, Diem in Vietnam, Idi Amin in Uganda and Somoza in Nicaragua. In every case, sanctions often coupled with the threat of military action have produced the desired result. India in 1989 blockaded Nepal and forced changes there which have given at least some measure of democratic rights to the people of Nepal.
Of course we have the historic example of sanctions working against South Africa. Many countries avoided the sanctions against South Africa in a totally hypocritical and frankly illegal way. Still, with all of that, the sanctions imposed primarily through the Commonwealth and by other countries over a period of time eventually forced the government of South Africa to change its policies and to begin to bring that country back into the international community and to begin the process of change in South Africa.
We even saw the use of something as simple as a sport boycott having an enormous effect on the psychology and people of South Africa and eventually helping to create the conditions in that country so that relatively peaceful change could take place. In fact, South Africa may be an example where an invasion, the use of military force, would simply not work given the size of the minority white community. What was necessary was the long build-up of economic and psychological pressure on at least a significant portion of that minority to begin recognizing that change was absolutely vital. So we have seen that work there.
We see less effectiveness in Haiti. In fact, if the Government of the United States particularly would seize the assets of rich Haitians in the United States, we might begin to see the kind of change that is necessary in Haiti. Clearly, comprehensive, effective economic sanctions in Haiti are absolutely essential and should be fully supported and pressure kept up by the Canadian government.
This coming week or next week, the Secretary of State for External Affairs will be meeting the foreign minister of Indonesia, a country which has grossly violated the human rights of the people of East Timor. It will be very interesting to see how the government conveys the message there. Again, selective sanctions against Indonesia would be, in my view, absolutely essential at building the pressure on Indonesia to end its repression of the people of East Timor. The government has imposed a very, very limited boycott on certain sales and certain relations with Indonesia. It is interesting that it has not intervened against the sale of military products to Indonesia and has not done an effective job in calling for international sanctions against that country so that the people of East Timor may be restored their rights.
Let me conclude with a few comments on Iraq because it seems that the experience that the world community had last year on the issue of sanctions in Iraq is very important for studying how this bill not only is important, but the policies which should prevail when the government is considering the use of the powers provided for in this bill.

There is no doubt now that if sanctions had been allowed to work then, the Government of Iraq would have eventually had to withdraw from Kuwait. I may say President of the United Nations and some day it may not be such a slip as all that.

to seek the removal from office of a leader of another country, particularly by assassination or other methods.

Mr. Speaker, I am delighted to have an opportunity to speak on this bill.
I am actually delighted that the government has put it on the floor of the House of Commons at this time. For the last three months I have been going through a personal experience that relates directly to this bill. I want to begin by giving a little bit of background on my interest in this bill specifically.
Last November I received a call from Michael Homsi, who is a constituent of mine in Broadview-Greenwood. He said: "Dennis, I have family who live in Amman, Jordan who have friends and family who are living in Baghdad. They are suffering deep pain right now and they wondered if there was some way that Canada could organize United Nations approval to ship food from Canada to Iraq". They did not want this food donated; they wanted to pay for this food. It was a commercial transaction.
Now I had never had any experience with anything like this, and quite frankly I did not know where to begin. Fortunately, this particular day one of my colleagues, the member from Burin-St. George's, was at the United Nations in New York.
He happened to call me on another matter and I explained this situation to him. Within hours he had the secretary to the sanctions committee of the United Nations call me. He explained to me the process whereby a nation gets a certificate of approval.
I called the Department of External Affairs, spoke to a certain gentleman there by the name of Marcel Belec. I
must say I was impressed by his quick response and the support which he gave me in responding to this request for my constituent.
To make a long story short, within three days we received a certificate of approval. This certificate was from the United Nations and Canada. It is dated November 12, signed by Donald W. Campbell, deputy minister for international trade and the associate undersecretary of state for external affairs. He signed this certificate allowing us to send food from Canada to Iraq. I must tell you this is not a truckload of food; this is
40,000	tonnes of food. It is a lot of food.
It was conditional upon two things. The first condition was that the order would be monitored by the United Nations from the shipping routes, the distribution, the delivery system. It must be monitored by the United Nations.

We faxed all of this information to the Embassy of Iraq in Amman, Jordan and then the process of delay began.

Mr. Speaker, I welcome the opportunity to speak on this particular bill. We will support it. The bill is an act to provide for the imposition of special economic measures or, in more commonly used terms, sanctions.
Over the years our party has taken the position that sanctions are a more much effective tool for peace and
Government Orders
for effective foreign policy than anything which might lead to the use of military force. We are talking about non-violent sanctions. Those can be defined as anything that will impose a cost on opponents or may change their behaviour but do not threaten human lives or cause physical injury.
Many of the approaches we have taken over the years as a country have not fallen into that category particularly, because we have in the end used sanctions that have done a considerable amount of harm to individuals mentally and physically.
The purpose of this bill is to improve the government's ability to impose a broad range of economic sanctions during or in anticipation of an international crisis. The sanctions suggested are much broader than are generally considered. As the minister indicated, the circumstances under which sanctions are now put into effect have changed considerably over the years. That is what the bill does.
What will this bill allow the government to do a little more thoroughly? Basically the proposed legislation would allow the government to apply measures such as the freezing of the assets in Canada that are held by another state, prohibiting or restricting the import and the export of goods and services, financial conversion transactions, air and sea links, plus restricting some activities of Canadians outside Canada.
Whenever a government applies such measures it allows the cabinet to put in place sanctions very quickly, without having to wait for an international organization such as the United Nations or the Organization of American States to make the basic decision.
In the past the Government of Canada has found it difficult to put sanctions in place because that authority has not been in place in any particular act. Only by the United Nations Act could it make that move, or it could do it specifically in certain areas. That has made it particularly awkward and therefore it was unable to act on its own. This bill will attempt to make it easier for the government to do so.
Even as we support the bill, we have some concerns and we have some reason to believe that there is a need to look very closely at particular parts of the bill. I hope this will be done during the committee process. I suppose we have a half-dozen concerns. Some of them are minor,

but they are basically concerns which we think need to be discussed very thoroughly.
One of the suggestions or sanctions in this particular bill gives the government the authority to seize property or freeze property in the country. Apparently the intent of this is to freeze assets of someone like Marcos from the Philippines who may come to Canada or may have some assets in Canada. However, this has not always been the effect of the freezing of sanctions in the past and it may not be in the future. If a blanket suggestion like this is put in place, there is always someone who is going to be hurt.
The refugee who lives in Canada and has property in Canada or a business in Canada could be affected by such a freeze, if he still is a citizen of a foreign country on which Canada is going to impose sanctions.
There is another part of that particular sanction which I think is dangerous as well. We may wish to delete it to some extent or at least alter it to some extent in committee. I am referring to the ability of the government under these circumstances, if it puts sanctions in place, freezes property or seizes property, to sell portions of the property to pay for the cost of seizing and taking care of the property.
This is dangerous. I hesitate to draw a parallel between what happened to the Japanese in Canada in the last war, but there are some similarities. The property of almost all the Japanese who were forced to move away from the coast and into the central part of Canada was seized and sold. The reason for that was not because the people could not take care of the property but because of the greed of the people in the surrounding areas who wanted control of the property.
There was no national interest in the sale of the property. The sale of the property was done for reasons which were not of any value to Canada. That is not a particularly happy part of our history and it could be repeated in the circumstances which are in this particular bill. I do not think we would want that to happen.
The intent may be good, but I know this is not the reason it was put there. It should be looked at to make sure that it does not happen to hurt not only our people but people from all over the world.
This is not an unusual situation. We will find, without question, numbers of examples where people are returned to their homes and find that the property they once owned has been confiscated by a government, sold for costs which the government says it had, and is no longer available to those people. That is highly unfair and highly unacceptable in our kind of democracy.
There is a second section that we should look at very closely, and that is the section on compensation within this bill, subclause 6(3). This is compensation of citizens or people who are adversely affected by sanctions. Since the reason for putting sanctions in place is to affect a whole nation adversely, there are bound to be effects which are going to overlap into the areas of our citizenship or people we do not want to hurt.
The legislation in this area is very tentative. The Governor in Council may designate a minister to deal with claims. If cabinet overlooks this action, drags its feet, many of our citizens will be hurt or bear the brunt of there being nothing in this particular bill which will allow them to apply for compensation. There is no sort of automatic review of the idea that compensation may be necessary.
I can give a very specific example. When the United States put sanctions on the sale of grain to the Soviet Union after the invasion of Afghanistan, Canada under the Clark government of that particular time acquiesced and went along with it. In 1980 the Trudeau government also acquiesced to that particular request-and that is all it was-of the U.S. government to put in place the same sanction.
Canada in that particular circumstance, because of single desk selling and because we had control of the grain that was sold out of Canada, was the only country able to police the sanction in such a way that there was no grain sold. The United States, for instance, sold to other countries and then it was diverted to the Soviet Union. It was a very surprising fact during that particular period of time, for instance, that Italy became a net exporter of wheat to the Soviet Union. Most of that wheat came from the United States and was transshipped to the Soviet Union. Much of it was not even unloaded in Italy.
Under those circumstances the price of wheat went down about $1 or $1.50 per bushel. Canadian farmers were the only people who were impacted by the United States sanctions on the Soviet Union. At the time I was the spokesman for grains and oilseeds for my party.
February 20, 1992

I and other members of the opposition, at that time the Conservative opposition, spent a year and one-half badgering the Trudeau government to pay some compensation because there was no automatic method by which compensation could be requested.
It came through eventually, but the process was very painful and it put our farmers at a disadvantage for a couple of years. They still have not recovered from that entirely.
Perhaps this bill should be made more specific. Instead of saying that the Governor in Council may appoint a minister, the bill probably should say the Governor in Council shall appoint a minister whose responsibility it will be to oversee compensation for sanctions when they affect Canadian citizens or other citizens of the world.
I have a couple of other major concerns which I would like to spend a little bit of time on.
Sanctions may bring a country to realize the error of its ways, if that is what is intended, but it is a two-edged sword. When economic sanctions are used, a cost may be imposed on the opponent, but there is also a cost imposed on the user of the sanctions. There may also be considerably greater costs to innocent bystanders. If there is a full international embargo on any particular country, then there are bound to be certain bystanders affected.
I think we need to look at those innocent bystanders and who they are. As a number of previous speakers have indicated, the best examples that we have right now probably are the starving Iraqi children and the situation with the Kurds which are results of the war in Iraq.
We know that the effect of economic sanctions on Iraq has resulted in the starvation of many children. That needs to be considered when those sanctions are extended.
I agree with the previous speaker, the hon. member for Broadview-Greenwood, who suggested that there are ways in which sanctions can be kept, but humanely.
In the particular case of Iraq, Eric Hoskins, who is a Canadian physician who participated in the Harvard study group that was formed to look at the impact on
Government Orders
Iraqi civilians, has urged the Canadian government to use some of the frozen Iraqi assets to purchase food and medicine for the Iraqi population.
The British have already done this. They have effectively released some food and medicine by using frozen assets which the Iraqi had in Britain.
It becomes very important to understand that that kind of sanction can do much more harm than we realize it will do.
So just to summarize, we will support the bill.
But we recognize a number of weaknesses that must be dealt with in committee. The weakness of compensation must be dealt with as well as the lack of a humanitarian base always being in place when sanctions are put in place.
We are not happy with the idea that only cabinet can make the decision as to when sanctions can be put in place. It must be a much broader base than it has been in the past.
We will support the bill but we hope that during committee these changes will be put into effect.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to make some comments about this bill that would impose sanctions against certain countries. I wonder why the government, at this point, brings forward such a bill.
As we know, during the debate on the gulf crisis the government was saying very forcefully that sanctions do not work. This was one of the arguments when they wanted to go to war. They said: "Sanctions are not working and if we do not act fast, the children of Iraq are going to suffer and the population of Iraq is going to suffer".
We know what happened. We went to war. More bombs were thrown on Iraq and Kuwait than during World War II. It brought about the destruction of Kuwait. It brought in ecological damage to the Persian Gulf and today the children in Iraq are starving. The Kurds have been displaced. There is tremendous human suffering because at that time the government said: "Sanctions do not work".

February 20, 1992
Government Orders
I am quite proud that I voted against that war because it did not solve the problem, it just aggravated the problem.
Suddenly, the government, in the name of a new world order as proclaimed by President Bush, now says: "We want you to give us carte blanche so we can impose sanctions when we wish."
This bill is flawed. The government does not need carte blanche. If it wants to impose sanctions against any nation, it can go back to Parliament and get a mandate to impose sanctions.
I do not see many members on the other side who are going to speak to this bill. Most of them have said that sanctions are not effective and that is why we had to go to war to bring a fast resolution to the conflict in the gulf.
I listened to a member of the Liberal Party who was indicating why it is very difficult to have sanctions and then bring humanitarian help.
If we freeze the assets of a country like Iraq and it wants to buy grain from Canada and it cannot use that money to feed the starving population, what is the use of having these types of sanctions?
Therefore, I cannot support this bill. If it is amended in an extreme form, then maybe I would, but I doubt it. The bill is flawed. At the present time the government does not need a bill like this. If there is ever a crisis it can always come back to Parliament and ask Parliament to impose sanctions against a given population.
I would also like to draw attention to what the previous speaker said about the confiscation of assets of Japane-se-Canadians during World War II and how those assets were disposed of. It certainly brought injustice to those people who were Canadians. It shows that if there is a bill that gives the government carte blanche, it is not going to be in the best interests of Canada.
I just wanted to make that comment and maybe ask a question to the previous speaker.
I know that the New Democratic Party did not support the war in the gulf. They felt that we should proceed with sanctions. He just told us that they are going to
support the bill, maybe not in its present form, but they are going to support it, whatever the end result is.
How can he square his position that gives the government carte blanche to impose sanctions against any nation by Order in Council? How does he find that acceptable?

Mr. Speaker, we would all have to say that we could not support the Bush administration position during the Iraqi war that the sanctions were not going to work. Those sanctions were pre-empted after only five and one-half months, whereas we know that sanctions do take longer than that. That pre-emption of those sanctions was a mistake.
If the objective of the sanctions was the withdrawal of the Iraqis from Kuwait, it is my feeling and the feeling of many other people across the world that the reason the Bush administration withdrew or pre-empted those sanctions was not because they were afraid they would not work. They were afraid they would work.
Their aim in this particular Iraqi war was not necessarily Kuwait. It was the smashing of the Saddam Hussein government and if sanctions worked, then they would not be able to do that. In the end it did not work either way.
To answer your question specifically, we have hope that any government that will be in place will look at the need for sanctions. We hope there will be enough safeguards within the bill when we get it back to the House that we can be sure that what is done is for the best interests of Canada and not for the best interests of the Bush administration.
