speakeroldname: Hon. Jake Epp (Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources) moved
speakerposition: Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources
speechtext:
that Bill C-41, an act respecting the energy efficiency of energy using products and the use of alternative energy sources, be read the second time and referred to Legislative Committee D.
He said: Madam Speaker, prior to starting my comments I want to indicate to my critics opposite that if I leave and do not listen to them, it is not that I would want to leave but I have to host the President of Moldova for lunch. I hope that is understood if I slip away.
I am pleased to be leading off second reading debate on Bill C-41, the energy efficiency act. It is a major challenge facing a government in that it is to find methods of improving energy efficiency across the Canadian economy. By being energy efficient, Canadian consumers can reduce energy expenditures and businesses can become more competitive. Moreover, being energy efficient helps to improve air quality, to preserve water and land resources, and to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
Of particular concern to many countries is the concentration in the atmosphere of greenhouse gases and their potential to affect the climate. The federal government's strategy to address the global issue is outlined in the green plan. Reflecting the nature of our federation and jurisdictional responsibilities, federal, provincial and territorial governments are working co-operatively to develop a national action strategy on global warming.
I want to commend the standing committee on energy, its chairman as well as the members of that committee. I appeared before them earlier this week and we had a discussion on this issue. They have been doing a lot of work and I look forward to their findings.
Improved energy efficiency is one of the more important components of the strategy. However, governments,
Government Orders
both federal and provincial, alone cannot solve this problem. Individuals and organizations need to re-examine how we use energy and there is much room for improvement. Using energy more efficiently is an important first step. To help Canadians use energy more wisely, we have brought forward Bill C-41 for Parliament's consideration, and I use those words "Parliament's consideration" in the best of parliamentary tradition because it is in this area where we can get new ideas and where we can improve on the type of legislation that we are bringing before Parliament that I think can be improved through committee work.
I am convinced that there are many economic opportunities at all levels of Canadian society to be more efficient, especially in the manner in which we use energy. We want to seize these opportunities, opportunities which will benefit both the environment and the economy. Provincial governments, industry associations, community groups and individuals across Canada have already started putting into place promising solutions to our energy efficiency challenges.
I have been particularly struck by the way Canada's electricity supply sector has taken up demand-side management. For example, a few months ago I saw an agreement regarding my department's participation in the activities of Power-Smart Incorporated. This agency was established by B.C. Hydro to assist in the development and delivery of demand side management. Its membership, since those days when I met with them first in Vancouver, has expanded over the years. It now includes 15 Canadian utilities as well as my department. We are now working with Power-Smart and our fellow members on the details of an even further co-operative promotional plan.
Our participation in this enterprise emphasizes our commitment to energy efficiency. It also stresses our conviction to work in partnership to achieve those goals. Bill C-41 is another clear signal of the government's commitment to efficient use of energy. The principle function of the energy efficiency act is to provide the statutory authority for the new efficiency and alternative energy program which was announced in the green plan which we discussed in committee earlier this week.
This program will involve all fuel types in energy using sectors of the economy. It will provide focused support for each sector through initiatives employing targeted information programs, persuasion, regulation and re-

February 20,1992
Government Orders
search and development. These initiatives will have net environmental and net economic benefits. Environmentally they will reduce all of the major atmospheric emissions associated with energy use, including those that contribute to acid rain and urban smog. Moreover, by deferring the construction of new energy production and transportation facilities, these initiatives will also result in less degradation of land and water quality.
Additionally the federal initiatives will help strengthen the Canadian economy. This strengthening will result by encouraging investment in energy efficiency and alternative energy technologies.
Canadian consumers who consider energy efficiency more carefully when making their purchasing decisions will be able to reduce their annual energy costs, thereby freeing some of their income for other uses.
Additionally Canadian industry can lower its energy costs, raise productivity and improve its international competitiveness. Furthermore, there is a growing international interest in competitive products as well as technologies and services offering energy efficiency or employing alternative energy sources.
Canadian companies responding to increased domestic demand for such products and services will also gain international opportunities to expand those markets.
Let me give you an example, Madam Speaker, because a lot of this can become very theoretical. An excellent example, I think, of how energy efficiency can benefit the economy is the recent announcement by General Electric (Canada) that it will invest $144 million in its plant at Oakville, Ontario. It is going to do that to supply two new energy efficiency lighting products.
Often we hear about obsolescence in our manufacturing base. This is a reversal, and I think a very happy synergy between the economy and the environment. This new manufacturing capacity will serve a world market, and it is expected that half the production will be exported from our country.
As a result of this investment, 190 new jobs will be created. An example of the area of energy efficiency
services, for example, that shows that we can even go beyond products or tangible items for export sales is that we now have membership from Mexico and Czechoslovakia in Power-Smart. The opportunities for job creation and world markets are there, and it is gratifying to see companies seizing these opportunities.
Our new package of initiatives is designed to be prudent. We hope it is balanced and we think it is co-operative. It is directed at overcoming the barriers obstructing the realization of economic opportunities to increase the efficiency of energy use and the utilization of alternative energy sources in Canada. It will involve all fuel types and energy using sectors in the economy.
Members, I am sure, will be interested in knowing that over the next few weeks I will be making announcements again relating to efficiency and alternative energy program initiatives that came from the green plan.
Many hon. members will know as well that I announced in October the three initiatives directly related to the energy efficiency act. They are energy efficiency standards for equipment, Energuide labelling and the national energy use data base.
In November I announced five initiatives aimed at encouraging a more energy efficient building industry in Canada. I have had a lot of meetings with the Canadian Home Builders' Association as well as some provincial organizations. For example, the building energy code initiative will update and rename the federal government's measures for energy conservation in new buildings. When this is complete, we will look to provincial and municipal governments to incorporate these measures in their building codes.
The building information transfer initiative will support increased public and housing industry awareness of the value of energy efficiency. One of the most successful programs, the R-2000 program, is a R-2000 partnership initiative which will upgrade the current R-2000 standard, give greater recognition of environmental consideration and increase market penetration through regional partnerships with governments and utilities.
February 20, 1992

I will just spend a moment on this, Madam Speaker. The R-2000 licensing program has now been arranged with Japan for building products in Japan. Generally we as Canadians think that we do not have the same technology levels as the Japanese. On R-2000, it is the opposite. We have brought the R-2000 program to Japan.
I can say, and I do not want to be too parochial, but manufacturers of windows and doors in my own area, in my riding and in my own province are using the R-2000 factor and are now starting to penetrate the Japanese market. It is slow work, it is expensive to get into the market, but the R-2000 seems to have helped, almost like a seal of Good Housekeeping for those markets.
Additionally our enhanced buildings research, development and technology transfers activities, such as the advanced houses programs, will focus on lab testing, field trials and the transfer of technology to the building sector. I have announced that there are nine winners of innovative housing across the country in which we are going to bring additional technology and hopefully use in it a demonstration in different technologies, different climates, different regions and that they will be transferred to the housing sector as well.
All of this is being done co-operatively with the housing industry and not independently by government alone. As well, through the federal buildings initiative, EMR will assist the federal government departments to improve the energy efficiency of their facilities without compromising the work environment of employees.
I want to thank my colleague, the President of the Treasury Board, who is here today. I am sure he came just to hear me say this. So often in government we are frustrated by the fact that we can get a practical idea and it seems that the system just does not allow us to implement a practical idea. We went to Treasury Board and to Ontario Hydro and we said: "Here is a deal that you cannot refuse".
In my experience that generally does not get you very far. They find a reason to refuse you. The deal was this to Treasury Board. We will do an energy audit, and we have done an energy audit, of some 1,600 federal government buildings. I am not trying to be partisan about this. When there was a change of government in the province of Ontario, it mandated Ontario Hydro to do it for the Ontario government buildings because of the success we are having here.
Government Orders
Then what we did was this. We said to Treasury Board: "You are giving us x number of dollars per year for energy in these buildings. Keep us at this level of expenditure. We will bring in energy efficiency and the saving. We will work with a consulting company and with that saving we will pay back the costs of the new installations".
Coming from a very practical world, in which I live, I thought that made a lot of sense. I want to thank the President of the Treasury Board today. Since we presented the idea, they have only been co-operative. Despite rumours to the contrary, they can work with great alacrity and speed and I want to thank them.
Madam Speaker, I will speak about your throne in a minute because that is also part of this program. That will come a little later in my notes.
That is in the buildings area. I think it is innovative and it is working. We can transfer that also into industry.
As well, in December I announced two new alternative transportation fuel measures. The technology and market department component will expand the use of gaseous and alcohol fuel through incentives, market demonstrations, technology transfers and information assistance. The second measure will support research and development to increase progress in the fields of liquid and gaseous fuels and electrically based technologies.
I cannot make these announcements on behalf of my colleague the Minister of Transport, but I direct my colleagues in the House to the press today. As you will see, there has been further advancement made in this field by the ministry of transport. They will want to announce it in a more formal way than simply through the press.
The principal function of Bill C-41 is to provide the statutory authority for the federal energy efficiency initiatives related to energy labelling, minimum energy efficiency standards and collection of statistics and information.
With regard to labelling and energy efficiency standards, the bill will facilitate enhancement of the existing Energuide, a labelling program which applies to refrigerators, ranges, ovens, freezers, dishwashers, clothes dryers and washers. The program requires that new appliances bear a specified label providing information on a product's energy efficiency which consumers can

February 20,1992
Government Orders
use to make the most energy-wise purchasing decision. Bill C-41 will transfer statutory authority for the Ener-guide program and its regulations from Consumer and Corporate Affairs to EMR Canada, thereby bringing the program under the umbrella of the efficiency and alternate energy program. This will simplify the regulatory and consultative process through which we will update, expand and enhance the Energuide program.
One enhancement will be the redesigning of the label to one that will be easier to read and comprehend. In addition, stronger promotional campaigns will encourage consumers to buy the most energy efficient equipment on the market.
Research and development initiatives under our program will result in more energy efficient products coming on to the market. Minimum efficiency standards will reinforce this improvement by removing inefficient items from the marketplace. In fact, in the right circumstances new products and processes have significant export value. We discussed that as well in the committee recently this week.
While minimum energy efficiency standards will be new at the federal level, in recent years B.C., Ontario along with federal and some state governments in the U.S., have established energy efficiency regulations on several products. Quebec and Nova Scotia have passed enabling legislation in this area and other provinces are considering taking similar actions.
What was developing was a patchwork of energy efficiency standards. Inconsistent standards could prove to be very detrimental. For example, we were seeing that some provinces were becoming dumping grounds for the continent's most inefficient products. In other words, you cannot sell an inefficient product in a jurisdiction that now has passed regulations or legislation, and so it was being made available in other provinces. As well, interprovincial trade could be impaired. It is for these reasons that we are coming in with a national bill.
Consequently there have been requests from both the provinces, the territories, not to mention industry-industry has been very much a part of this-that the federal government exercise its constitutional authority over interprovincial and international commerce in order to help establish a consistent national energy efficiency regulatory regime. This need to avoid interprovincial trade barriers was another point underlined as well in the Porter study on Canadian competitiveness.
Such regulatory action will only be taken following even more consultation with affected parties. Such regulations will be developed so as to avoid unnecessary costs to manufacturers and to facilitate co-ordination with provincial authorities. They will be developed with due regard to Canada's international trade obligations as well as industry's concern that it not be placed in an uncompetitive position.
We will be seeking consistency with standards in provincial and American jurisdictions, and the federal regulatory process ensures that Canadians have the opportunity to comment on these draft regulations.
Part II of Bill C-41 concerns the collection and use of statistics pertaining to the efficiency of energy use and the adoption of alternative energy sources. In the formulation of energy efficiency and alternate energy policy, we have been conscious of our responsibility to evaluate the effectiveness of measures included in that policy and to measure the contribution of energy users to the goal of stabilizing greenhouse gas emissions.
We also wanted to create a solid foundation for possible further measures, not only in terms of facilitating their implementation, but with regard to optimizing their design as well. Furthermore, we knew that in order for Canadians to respond effectively to the threat of global warming we would need to know more about how we use energy in this country.
Both Statistics Canada and EMR have been collecting statistics on the energy industry for some years. My Alberta friends will know this better than most. The focus of these efforts has been at the aggregate level or the financial information. There has been some modest collection of information on energy at the end use level and on alternative sources of energy. This has been done mainly outside of government and the available data are sparse.
In discussing the need for satisfactory data in this area, both departments felt it would be more efficient and expeditious for EMR to pursue the matter as long as
February 20, 1992

every effort was made to avoid duplication and obviously this information was to be made public. Consequently, our new efficiency and alternative energy program provides for the creation of a national energy use data base which will integrate existing sources of data on energy use and develop and organize new data sources.
We will also seek a clearer understanding of the factors that influence the level of energy usage and what influences companies and householders in their decisions to adopt or ignore certain types of energy using technologies. Again, this will be carried out with Statistics Canada.
We hope that most of the data and information we require can be obtained from existing data bases held by StatsCanada and others from voluntary surveys. If this approach proves inadequate, the Energy Efficiency Act will provide the authority to ensure that necessary information is obtained.
In undertaking any of our regulatory activities we will be conscious of the fact that regulation is a policy tool which, I believe, must be used in moderation. So often it is so easy to say that we will pass another regulation. We will control people by doing this.
I feel comfortable about this bill because in looking at the regulatory side we had a lot of consultations. I wanted to have consultations with consumers and industry because if it is simply another barrier to competitiveness then we have to look at that as well. We have taken full account of these considerations and our regulator initiatives, we believe, are effective and efficient in advancing those objectives we have, because to intervene in the marketplace is a decision which I believe should not be taken lightly. It should be taken very seriously.
Wherever possible, we have sought to reduce the amount of regulation in the country in order to eliminate unnecessary burdens, in order to eliminate those on industry, small business and the public. I can say very definitely that if industry and consumers alike had not wanted to move in this direction, I would have had some serious reservations. Therefore, we have been painstaking in considering their advice. We have been doing this
Government Orders
also with utilities and we have structured these authorities which we are now creating under Bill C-41.
By reconsidering how we use energy and by making more informed and responsible choices, we can save money, help the environment and at the same time demonstrate leadership to the international community in its efforts to come to grips with the issue of global climate change.
Like any organization, the federal government is an energy consumer, subject to the same energy efficiency challenges as other Canadians. Within the Department of Energy, Mines and Resources, as I have pointed out, we now have a program known as the Federal Buildings Initiative. In fact, Madam Speaker, I know you will remember from the Speaker's office that we demonstrated to you and to the press, the economic, low cost energy options that have been adopted here in this House.
Together with my colleague the Minister of Public Works, we toured the ceremonial walk which is taken by the Sergeant-at-Arms, pointing out the energy efficiency lighting, the retrofit possibilities. In concert with Public Works and Ontario Hydro, we will follow up these possibilities as well as look at the energy efficiency options for Parliament Hill's long-term energy management needs.
When we were in this Chamber the Speaker sat down in the Speaker's chair and pointed out that the lighting is now changed. I know, Madam Speaker, that this would never apply to you, but he thought that while it might not help in the ability for him to again find the hair he lost-I know you do not have that problem-he thought the lighting was an improvement.
We are trying to be very practical in this place and show very clearly and demonstrate very clearly what we are doing.
In all of these issues there is an overriding consideration. Often Canadians will use the argument or hear the argument made that Canada uses more energy than any other country and, therefore, by extension we are profligate.
Because it is colder.

My hon. friend calls from across the House, because it is cold here.
I want to relate a small incident I had when I attended my first-

speechtext:
You might, but I can't.
At the first meeting of the International Energy Agency the minister from Sweden happened to be the minister of the environment and of energy. She took Canada on fairly strongly about our profligate ways. As you know, we all defend our country when we are abroad, and I asked officials for the statistics from her country. When I had the chance to intervene I said: "Madam Speaker, I see that your unit use is not much less than Canada's, and might I suggest it has more to do with latitude than attitude".
I think sometimes we as Canadians want to put ourselves almost in sackcloth and ashes. The fact of the matter is that we have a large country. We have a northern climate. We have a sparse population. And so it is in that context that I have to look at these bills as well.
Additionally we also have abundant energy and as a result we have moved into industries which utilize that abundance of energy. It creates jobs; it creates quality of life.
I fully accept as minister of energy that we have to be more energy efficient but we should not fall into the trap, or hear the siren call that I hear so often that all you have to do is regulate people and force change and behavioural change upon them and all these things will change. The fact of the matter is that if you look today at the press, the first half of Question Period often drives the opposition by "why are you losing these industries, why are these jobs lost, why are these towns closing?"
Because of the GST, because of the GST.

speakerposition: Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources
speechtext:
The second half is exactly the argument. I hear my colleague from Quebec. I know he knows a lot about lemons and I guess that is why he keeps repeating what he says. As a result, I say to him that the issue has to be balanced, it has to be balanced between the objectives of the environment and the economy.
That is the job of the Minister of Energy. I have said that that will be my objective. I believe this bill is balanced, balanced between those two objectives, helping Canadian industry, helping Canadian consumers, and
moving us in a direction which will help our competitiveness.

Madam Speaker, I only wish things were as simple as we have just heard from the minister of energy. As he has indicated, and I would appreciate him doing so earlier when he leaves for his lunch, but perhaps he would prefer to leave now rather than when I get going because I do not think he is going to like what I say very much and I suspect he is not going to like very much what the critic for the New Democratic Party has to say about this bill.

speakerposition: Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources
speechtext: I'd rather stay.

The bill opts for a regulatory rather than a common sense approach, presumably to foster an impression among Canadians, of whom I note that 11 per cent today indicate they would be prepared to support the re-election of this government. My question is, who are these 11 per cent of Canadians? I would like to talk to them.
The intention is to foster the impression that the government wants to achieve substantial energy savings. Federal officials are to be given the right to inspect any electric appliance shipped across our border. If they find something, for example, a furnace or a toaster that is deemed to waste energy, they will under the bill have the right to confiscate and destroy it at the former owner's expense.
It is the Income Tax Act model which, in many respects, still implies that the citizen and his or her property belong to the government, instead of vice versa. It rather reminds you of a visit to the former East Germany before the Berlin Wall came down.
Instead of a law which mirrors existing American ones, which years ago prompted the manufacture of energy-efficient appliances, thus of course causing the dumping of electricity guzzling ones in Canada, our minister of energy is only now attempting to close the barn door.
It might look quite good if one is unaware of our energy waste realities. In fairness to the bill, regulations would phase out some inefficient equipment from the Canadian market, but as Friends of the Earth put it in a letter recently to my office: "According to the Ontario ministry of energy the federal act as proposed has an import loophole. The focus on dealer means that an individual importing an energy using product for his or
February 20, 1992

her own use, that is not for resale, is exempt from the act".
If that view of Friends of the Earth is correct, the bill is even more toothless than one might have supposed. The regulatory approach invariably will create other problems including predictable side effects.
For example, in a fairly recent brief to the Standing Committee on Energy, Mines and Resources, the Canadian Electrical Association gave the example of the recently amended requirement for Ontario building contractors to submit bids for non-profit housing contracts on the basis of lowest first cost. This encouraged the use of electric baseboard heating, the least efficient and economical choice from available heating systems. Is that not official madness from an energy efficiency standpoint?
In the same brief the Electrical Association provided some striking examples of regulatory barriers that discourage innovative approaches to developing new environmentally benign technologies.
Public utilities across Canada today are still barred by government regulations from permitting a joint govem-ment-industry-utility technology demonstration developed in one jurisdiction to be brought into the rate base of utilities outside that jurisdiction. Short lead time projects are favoured over longer lead time projects which may be more energy efficient.
The bill we are discussing aims at achieving energy savings in the residential sector. However, I quote from the government's 1990 discussion paper entitled Energy Use and Atmospheric Change: "The equipment initiatives (and these include commercial, institutional and industrial equipment, not only household appliances) are expected to account for about 25 per cent of total energy savings in the year 2000". The same study estimates that about 28 per cent of total energy savings by the year 2000 could be achieved through transportation initiatives and 27 per cent through industry initiatives.
Moreover, within the equipment initiatives, and I quote from the same source, "the largest simple impact on energy use is projected to result from the increase in the energy efficiency of residential and commercial lighting".
The bill before us is entirely silent on this issue. Yet it has become common knowledge that compact fluores-
Govemment Orders
cent lamps consume 75 per cent to 85 per cent less electricity than do incandescent ones and last nine to thirteen times longer than ordinary bulbs.
Why the deafening silence? According to Rocky Mountain Institute calculations, efficient lighting hardware now available for almost any application would reduce in the U.S. the need for about 70 billion to 120 billion watts of power plants. Those plants would cost from $85 billion to $200 billion to build and from $18 billion to $30 billion a year to operate.
Road transport accounts for 30 per cent of Canada's energy use currently and almost 70 per cent of our total petroleum requirements. In all industrialized countries the energy gobbled up by transport exceeds that going to the residential and service sectors together. Instead of targeting the residential sector, any responsible energy efficiency act, which this one in my view clearly is not, should target the users who consume and pollute the most.
Besides, as pointed out by Friends of the Earth, the federal act as proposed only applies to "energy using products". That means that products which do not use energy but affect energy efficiency such as doors, windows and so on are not covered by the act.
The need and obligation to collect data and improve knowledge on the activities of every sector of our economy by appropriate federal institutions cannot really be questioned today. Therefore, the inclusion of the national energy use data base section in the proposed act surprises one, to say the least. Is the government telling Canadians that it intends to find out in the foreseeable future what is actually going on in our country's energy sector, or does it really want to equip its energy department offices with a brand new computer system with more borrowed tax dollars?
Isn't the collection of statistics on energy use a fundamental duty and routine procedure of the federal department responsible for the energy policy of this country? Its inclusion in the energy efficiency act tends to demolish any notion of competence of this government on energy matters.
At the heart of the debate on energy efficiency conservation and alternative energy sources is the widespread public concern about our natural environment. The effects of intensive energy consumption take the

Government Orders
form of acid rain, smog, global warming, depletion of the ozone layer, toxic waste disposal, and so on. The burning of carbon based fossil fuel still accounts for most of Canada's energy production.
Our energy consumption is expected to double by the year 2020 which raises the question as to whether such growth can continue unchecked.
Improved energy efficiency is the cheapest and fastest way to better our energy consumption patterns. Efficiency improvements are estimated to be about seven times more effective in reducing CO2 emissions per dollar invested than other methods. A policy of active conservation based on the deliberate development of new technologies is a viable alternative to supply side policies aimed at increasing our output of energy. Conservation is by the way also more labour intensive.
Making houses in our constituencies more energy efficient, upgrading lighting equipment in offices, installing more efficient motors all provide new employment for skilled Canadians and create demand for equipment and supplies.
Despite all its Reaganomics rhetoric and extensive deregulation of energy prices in trade since 1985, this federal government continues to intervene in our energy market most notably through subsidies to energy megaprojects and oil and gas exploration.
The government is also a friend of our nuclear industry through regulations, tax policies and very generous yearly subsidies. Meanwhile, programs in conservation and alternative energy sources have been eliminated or cut down since 1984. Subsidizing some types of energy supply production while cutting back subsidies to energy conservation distorts the competitiveness of energy options and increases the negative environmental impact of federal energy policy.
Conservation and alternative energy sources came into sharp focus during the 1970s when unstable political conditions in the Middle East resulted in oil price shocks felt around the world. Oil supply disruptions and price hikes were again experienced in 1979 as a result of the Iranian revolution. The problem reappeared with the invasion of Kuwait by Iraqi soldiers on August 2, 1990.
Consequently one of the major concerns among Canadian energy conservers in our alternative energy industry as a whole has been the "disgraceful" neglect and declining levels of support for Canada's alternative energy program since the unloved Mulroney government came into office in 1984.
The development of significant new energy sources normally takes decades to accomplish. Research cannot be turned on and off from one fiscal year to the next without doing great harm to research efforts. Because of the long lead times for introducing innovations and the long response time of the energy system, decisions taken today will have their full effect only in decades afterwards.
The Tory funding of energy conservation and renewable energy activities has shrunk from about $500 million in 1984 to $30 million in 1990-91. The modest expenditure contrasts sharply with the huge assistance to our nuclear industry, for example. In other words this government spends much more promoting expensive energy supply options than cheaper conservation options, which is economically and environmentally irrational. They call this Tory economics.
In 1984 the government initiated its cutbacks with the elimination of the energy division of the National Research Council that was conducting research into solar, wind and fusion energy, hydrogen, and other forms of renewable energy. In the budget cuts announced in April 1989, only six months after being re-elected, the government shut down its branch offices in the provinces that provided information and grants for energy conservation and renewable initiatives. This was a pretty clear signal that the federal government was no longer committed to the prudent use of energy or interested in searching for new and innovative ways of keeping energy costs down.
The Conservation and Renewable Energy Office helped get funding for the Flair Homes Energy Demo that has helped give Winnipeg, which is close to the riding of the Minister of Energy, a reputation for being a centre of excellence in housing technology throughout North America. This has attracted the attention of building scientists from around the entire world.
February 20, 1992

The closure of the regional offices reinforced the trend away from conservation that has been present in other policy measures by the Department of Energy, Mines and Resources since 1984.
Valuable programs to advise industries on how to reduce energy consumption, to inform consumers about the energy efficiency of home appliances, to assist people to insulate their homes were all discarded. Our lack of improvement in recent years in energy use per capita can probably be attributed directly to the abandonment of energy efficiency programs in the mid to late 1980s.
A recent study done jointly by Friends of the Earth, Pollution Probe and the World Wildlife Fund entitled The Summit Environmental Accountability Project concluded that our progress has not only been poor in energy efficiency but also in CO2 emissions over the past five years. In 1990 the Government of Canada made a commitment to stabilize its emissions of CO2 at 1990 levels by the year 2000, and I am pleased that the minister reconfirmed that the other day before the energy committee.
The government's specific plan of action in the green plan very much appears to be still unclear months after it was announced and the proposed programs are inadequate to stabilize emissions. The green plan's original $5 billion budget has been slashed to $3 billion, and it would very much appear that it will be slashed even further. Absent from it is a comprehensive set of regulations and measures necessary for a significant reduction in CO2 emissions.
We Canadians could partially meet the stabilization targets through energy efficiency and conservation measures alone, but the government has simply not taken any substantive steps in that direction, nor has it estimated the cost of its CO2 emission abatement strategy. In fact CO2 emissions dropped by 27 per cent in the early 1980s but over the past eight years have increased by approximately 8 per cent. This is once again, partly at least, the result of federal government cuts to programs which would help Canadians generally to loosen the iron bond of oil.
The move away from energy conservation and efficiency is typical of Tory policy. In October 1989 the transport minister announced VIA Rail cuts that additionally hurt efforts to reduce CO2 emissions. Rail transport is more
Government Orders
environmentally benign than cars, but government made severe cuts to the service before considering the environmental implications. An environmental assessment document released after the decision had been announced was simply shelved.
Moving away somewhat from fossil fuels means that Canadians will have to choose between nuclear and renewable sources of power. In spite of all of the tax moneys directed over the years at nuclear power, we have not yet solved the problem of radioactive pollution generated at each stage of the nuclear fuel chain from uranium mining, milling, refining, fuel fabrication and transportation to reactor operation, to waste disposal. Disposal includes the reactors themselves at the end of their 30-year life-span.
If the government were involved in assisting the supply of "soft" energy to the same extent as nuclear technology, the economics of the renewable energy technologies would simply cease to be a problem. The technology is here today. It is commercially available despite an uneven playing field. Some are familiar with the Solar-wall system from Downsview, Ontario which proved to be an international success. Both Americans and Europeans are showing great interest in that product, which suggests that the Canadian renewable technologies are world class.
Photovoltaic technology has enormous potential in the far north. It is being used to provide electrical power to remote homes, for remote lighting, communications systems where installation of commercial power lines is prohibitively expensive and the price of diesel fuel is very high.
The federal government ought to increase R and D funding for renewable energy technologies. Some analyses show that it takes about 50 years for any new energy technology to become established as a significant producer of electricity. It is going to take many years for new construction techniques or new high efficiency motors, appliances and heating installations to make a substantial reduction in our energy consumption.
Canada for the time being has a yearly R and D budget for wind energy of around $700,000. The U.S. department of energy has an annual budget of $21 million for wind energy. The European community R and D budget

February 20,1992
Government Orders
hovers around $150 million annually for that type of research.
The government ought to initiate programs demonstrating the applications of renewable energy and energy management technologies.
Demonstration programs are an excellent way to introduce new technologies to the marketplace. They also assist the industry to market their products abroad, since the programs help to provide high profile evidence of domestic use of new technologies. This should be a very critical point in our foreign aid policies to the developing world.
As reported in Scientific American, economic projections show that if nothing is done to hasten energy technology development and to introduce existing efficiency technologies into developing countries, global climate change and other major environmental problems will escalate beyond acceptable levels.
Even if the so-called developed countries manage to reduce our CO2 emissions by 50 per cent, population growth and economic development in the so-called developing countries would most likely increase their CO2 emissions from 450 to about 900 kilograms per person annually by the year 2030. World-wide emissions of CO2 will then be 2.5 times of what they are per year now.
With the co-operation of the industrialized democracies, the developing countries could apply technical solutions that would promote economic growth while keeping energy demand growth relatively low. CIDA, our aid agency, should support the use of renewable energy forms in all energy-related foreign assistance.
Fossil resources will continue to be indispensable to our economy until we have a sustainable system built around renewable energy sources. This is beyond doubt.
Thus, from now on there will be a slow but continuous change from the heavy reliance on relatively cheap and easy oil and natural gas to an extended period of using fossil fuels that have potentially larger environmental impacts.
Eventually, Canadians will choose not to use fossil fuels because of the availability of cheaper and easier
alternatives. That the transition from the use of fossil fuels is inevitable is indisputable.
In the meantime, however, we must increase the efficiency of fossil fuel use by extracting the maximum energy from it while minimizing harm to the environment.
Tory energy policy appears to rest ultimately on the optimistic assumption of short-term price stability in the oil market followed by price increases in the mid-1990s and of growing American energy supply requirements, particularly in natural gas.
In 1986, however, that optimism was severely tested by the spectacular drop in world oil prices and by the chaos in the natural gas markets.
As one historian put it: "Within weeks of the fall of international prices companies were cutting back their exploration budgets, laying off personnel and asking for more and more government aid in an attempt to ride out this down side of the energy crisis. Alberta and Saskatchewan responded nervously with further cuts in royalties and taxes, while simultaneously demanding more help from Ottawa in the form of assistance in keeping the oilsands and other projects going when oil prices were rendering them temporarily uneconomic".
Those words by an historian aptly characterize the present condition of our vital oil and gas industry as well. In the first quarter of 1991 numerous companies have reported sizeable losses and the net oil and gas industry income for that period was the lowest in five years.
This poor performance is attributed to a set of complex and intertwined circumstances, including a wider gap between light and heavy crude oil prices, declining conventional production, outdated regulatory requirements, growing environmental demands and a several-year long decline in natural gas prices.
Unfortunately, according to many industry observers these trends are likely to continue, increasing the industry's operating loss and hurting profits. Inevitably one of the most tangible consequences of this will be even more jobs lost in a battered and vitally important Canadian industry.
February 20,1992

There is, as members from the west will know, virtually no major oil company that has not been forced to reduce its work force in recent years.
In Calgary, Gulf Canada Resources eliminated 250 jobs last May in an attempt to save between $30 million and $35 million by next year.
Imperial Oil has slashed 4,000 positions since 1989. Recently, more than 1,700 employees were laid off in a single swing of the axe, the same time it shut down 1,000 service stations, or at least announced the shutting down of them and reduced its refining capacity.
Since 1989 Petro-Canada has laid off about 1,500 employees nation-wide, only partly due to its drive to privatization. Last month it announced plans to close about 1,200 service stations across Canada.
Other major oil companies that have or will make major lay-offs include Amoco Canada, BP Canada, Husky Oil and Canada Northwest Energy.
Job losses tragically are now measured in the thousands and the western Canada oil patch could lose as many as 10,000 more livelihoods by 1995. That is careers, mortgages, children's education, demoralization, and it is social problems of all kinds.
The industry's work force peaked in 1985 at 140,000 and has declined steadily since then to 80,000. Last year more than 3,200 employees were laid off by major oil and gas companies alone. Mergers and downsizings are expected to increase-creating serious disturbances in the oil industry labour market.
In fact, I mentioned this the other day, I have a neighbour who goes to work each month, not in western Canada. He goes to work in North Yemen. He gets on an airplane, leaves his wife and two children, flies to North Yemen and works there for a month and then comes back to visit his family for a month, getting each alternative month off.
The question that many of us have is as to why can we not find work for him to do in Alberta, Saskatchewan, B.C., the Northwest Territories or somewhere in Canada, of course Hibernia included.
With bleak forecasts for the foreseeable future, temporarily laid-off professionals and others are not being rehired and many young people are not even considering careers in the oil and gas fields.

A shrinking, highly specialized work force puts an additional stress on the oil industry's efforts to maintain the technological edge which has kept our Canadian oil patch competitive internationally.
All that could backfire when oil and natural gas prices eventually improve and the crisis is hopefully over.
Recent bitter battles between the Alberta natural gas producers and the state of California are yet another reason for concern.
The notorious California Public Utilities Commission which is concerned only with the short-term interests of consumers and not with the long-term survival of producers, is unilaterally demanding radical changes to marketing arrangements with Alberta producers. It claims that the San Francisco based Pacific Gas and Electric Company has no obligation to honour long-term contracts with its suppliers.
Every day more than a billion cubic feet of western natural gas goes down the pipeline to California. For 30 years it has been a peaceful and mutually advantageous business. But political relations between Canada and the U.S. have changed to the point that what was formerly security of supply has become less of a concern for California consumers and the arguments are focusing now on price alone.
To no one's surprise, the Canadian Petroleum Association is outraged, saying that the California Public Utilities Commission-we call it CPUC in Alberta-"refute the sanctity of contracts" and that they "effectively violate the principle that buyers and sellers can negotiate market responsive contracts free of regulatory interference".
The bargaining that is being accompanied by a series of demands, threats and political manoeuvres may result in heavy cuts in the $1 billion western Canadians now earn annually in gas sales to California.
Moreover, should California's pricing policies emerge a winner, purchasers in Ontario might well be prompted to arrange the same deal for their gas consumers.
In fact, some institutional gas buyers in central Canada have reportedly refused to enter into long-term contracts with western Canada gas producers. That is also causing major problems for people who earn their living from oil and gas in my province.

February 20,1992
Government Orders
These are just some examples of how Tory policy has turned out to be wrong, threatening to undermine not only the economies of the government's so-called energy policy but also Canada's long term energy interests.
There has been no leadership in the areas of environmental protection and energy conservation. The Canadian public has been continuously misled by misleading promises by a government that nonsensically maintains that it is serious about taking action on changing our energy consumption patterns.
Probably the closest the government has come to supporting energy conservation, ironically was during the Persian Gulf crisis when its energy department began to promote conservation and efficiency in some ads.
In the Mulroney government constitutional proposals, the government wants to recognize, seemingly, the exclusive legislative jurisdiction of the provinces in sectors that are now treated in many cases as concurrent areas. These include tourism, forestry, mining and recreation.
I think many Canadians are likely to query whether the government will by implication simply opt out of a meaningful environmental role in, say, mining and forestry.
The notion that this government is now prepared to discuss transferring to the provinces exclusive authority over wildlife conservation and protection, soil and water conservation and so on is distressing.
Many Canadians are concerned that if that passes, all provinces will be pressured into an environmental bidding war with each other to attract new industry.
Allowing the provincial governments greater control over environmental regulations could well undermine any efforts at implementing nation-wide environmental standards. This might apply as well to the development and adoption of energy efficiency performance requirements for energy using equipment.
The housing industry and office factory buildings provide the government with an excellent opportunity to introduce effective conservation measures. Federally imposed standards could be incorporated into all plans
for insulation, low energy lighting, night storage water heating and so on.
Relegating to the provinces some exclusive areas of authority and competence in the area of environmental protection will probably only exacerbate interprovincial discrepancies and further reduce the regulatory coherence of the present federal government.
Many Canadians are painfully ignorant, unfortunately, about energy and environmental issues still. According to the Out of Balance report by the Standing Committee on the Environment: "Three in 10 Canadians actually believe that global warming is going to be positive for Canada".
Our increasingly electrical society has never before been asked to unplug computers, video games, fax machines, to turn down thermostats and to wear sweaters. Wearing more sweaters might help the textile industry in your province, Madam Speaker, and in Cornwall and elsewhere.
Even if energy saving technology is available now, how do we get people to buy it? The public must make a conscious decision to reduce its demand for fossil fuels, realizing that improved efficiency will not necessarily lead to a decline in living standards or in the work environment.
The introduction of energy efficient housing technologies, for example, is slower than it could be because many builders and architects are still unfamiliar with energy saving technologies.
Even more important, Canadians do not yet demand them. I understand that in comparison with the average home built in the United States, some super insulated homes in the state of Minnesota require 68 per cent less heat. For some residences in Sweden, the saving is 89 per cent.
Research done at the Lawrence Berkeley Centre for Building Science in California indicates that an $8 million investment in manufacturing and installing low emission windows would eliminate the need for 36 million barrels of oil which would cost $300 million to produce. The next federal government will have to take the responsibility to provide important kinds of information and education to our public.
February 20, 1992

Madam Speaker, you are probably thinking I have been going on for a long time. There is much more I could say. My party agrees with much scepticism to let this bill go to a legislative committee. Hopefully a host of changes can be made in committee.

Madam Speaker, might I, at the risk of violating the rules at the outset, express my regret that, due to his absence, I am unable personally to inform the minister that the New Democratic caucus supports this bill. I am unable to inform him through his parliamentary secretary as that good gentleman is as well absent. Let me ask the hon. member for Calgary Southwest if she would be so kind as to convey to the minister the fact that, in this matter at least, he will enjoy the support of the New Democrat caucus and we will work to facilitate the quick passage of this bill. We generally welcome any move, however small, to increase energy efficiency in the Canadian economy.
We recognize that this bill is only a shell. It is merely a mechanism, a nicety with which Parliament will give to the government the authority to pass regulations to effect the stated aims of the bill. In other words, we are not actually debating energy efficiency standards when we debate this bill. We are debating whether or not to give the government the authority to set energy efficiency standards.
I would note that this bill having passed, as I assume it will, the government thereafter should present to this House or, at the very least to the energy standing committee, the regulations it proposes to promulgate under the authority of the bill so that the meat of the matter can be debated and approved or rejected, as the case may be.
Unfortunately, even with those regulations, and although this bill is a positive development, it really amounts to little more than a drop in the bucket. In terms of fostering energy efficiency in our economy and in our personal lives, what Canadians required was a Great Dane. What this bill gives them is a Chihuahua. What Canadians required was a Mad Dog Vachon and what this bill gives them is a Green Gabled Anne. What Canadians required was a mighty oak. Alas, this bill far more properly could be deemed a bonsai rubber tree.
Government Orders
This is of a piece with the government's record in terms of energy efficiency. We cannot forget nor should we forget that this is the same government that has slashed its annual expenditures on energy conservation and alternatives by over 90 per cent since it was first elected in 1984. The Conservatives have reduced the budget for energy efficiency and conservation every year that they have been the government; in 1984-85 it was $410 million, in 1985-86 it was $207 million, in 1986-87 it was $100 million, in 1987-88 it was $89 million, in 1988-89 it was $74 million, in 1989-90 it was $49 million, in 1990-91 it will have been $40 million, and this year it will come in at something between $35 million and $39 million.
These are not just numbers that have been cut. These are not just tally sheet ledger entries. These are programs and activities that were intended to, and in many respects did, foster the wiser use of energy by Canadians. There were programs like the Canadian Home Insulation Program which provided contributions of up to $500 per household to save energy, by upgrading the thermal efficiency of existing homes and by encouraging good workmanship and practices in refitted houses.
The Canadian Energy Audit Program, the so-called CEAP, which provided free on-site audits of energy consumption patterns and suggested low cost maintenance adjustments to conserve energy is gone. There was the Atlantic Energy Conservation Investment Program which encouraged energy conservation in an area with high energy prices and few substitutes for imported oil and which resulted in improved buildings, industrial processes and manufacturing operations. It was cut.
I have more. The Solar Energy Demonstration Program, which developed cost effective applications for active solar energy technology and encouraged its use, resulted in over 12,000 domestic hot water systems and over 200 industrial solar systems being supported. That is gone out of the remote community development demonstration program. Pardon?

down. To say "tone down", I would never do that, but slow down and try to give a hand to the poor people who are keeping up and translating to French.

Thank you, Madam Speaker. I do apologize to the translators. It is, alas, my enthusiasm both for proper energy efficiency encouragement in this country on the one hand and for, in a sort of Calvinist sense, bringing to the attention of this government its sins on the other.
To continue, I hope at a slower pace, the Remote Community Demonstration Program which provided advice and financial support to 370 remote communities adopting energy alternative systems and conservation methods is gone.
Under the Forestry Industry Renewable Energy program, which provided financial assistance for biomass energy facilities, 180 projects were initiated on wood, municipal waste, agricultural waste and peat energy facilities. That is gone.
The Industrial Conversion Assistance Program, which provided one half of most capital costs to commercial, industrial and private institutions where they converted their boilers and heaters from heavy fuel oil to natural gas, is gone.
All of these programs which were in place, which were effecting the transition in Canadian industry and in Canadian homes from the less energy efficient to the more energy efficient use of energy are gone. They are gone with the wind. In the case of wind energy, gone without the wind.
On top of these program cuts, the Conservatives have also eliminated the Conservation and Renewable Energy Offices, the so-called CREOs. These were the major means that we had devised in Canada for taking what the experts and the bureaucrats know about energy efficiency and how to effect it, taking that information and distributing it to the people where the information can be used. Those, too, are gone.
It is a sad record of cuts. The government is only now beginning to turn its attention to reversing some of these horrendous program cuts. Even so, it is hard to get very enthusiastic about this minor turnaround. Funding for these efforts is pathetically small.
On Monday the Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources told the Standing Committee on Energy, Mines
and Resources that he expects the government will spend an additional $175 million on top of the $37 million already budgeted on energy efficiency and alternative energy. It sounds good. Keep in mind that that is actually less than the government budgeted for AECL, Atomic Energy of Canada Limited, for just this year. Unfortunately, the minister admitted that $175 million was not to be spent each year, but would be spread over six years, the life of the green plan.
Moreover, the minister said that that spending would not even necessarily be spread evenly over those six years, but let us be generous and say that it will be spread evenly over those six years. That means that government spending on energy efficiency and alternatives this year would amount to about $66 million in total. That is still less than the government spent for this purpose in fiscal 1988-89.
It is 84 per cent less than was spent the first year the Conservatives took office in 1984-85. Remember, it is not that the government does not have the money. The Mulroney Conservatives have consistently diverted money away from energy conservation, efficiency and alternatives to other less environmentally benign energy sources.
I have some examples.
When the government privatized Petro-Canada, thereby throwing away our valuable public energy company, a company that could have been used to encourage the use of more environmentally sound fuels like ethanol or to take the lead in recycling used engine oil and reclaiming air conditioning chemicals that deplete the ozone layer, the $520 million raised by the sale of the first 20 per cent of the company did not even go into government coffers. It went back to the company. So the government paid the investors for buying shares in a company that belonged to the taxpayer $520 million. I will not say it is madness, I will not say it is insanity, I will not say it is lunacy of the first rank, but I will say it is difficult to say it makes a lot of sense. Still, that is what they did. That is what they continue to do. The government slashed funding for VIA Rail, one of the most energy efficient modes of transportation, while supporting one of the most energy inefficient ones, air travel, by expanding the Toronto airport.
The Conservative government has seriously skewed what financing it does provide toward nuclear energy.
February 20, 1992

For example, the April 1991 corporate plan and budget summary for Atomic Energy of Canada Limited shows that the federal government has invested $4.5 billion in nuclear energy research and development over the last 40 years. That is $110 million every year for 40 years. In 1995-96 alone, Canadian taxpayers are expected to fork over another $197 million to Atomic Energy of Canada Limited.
It does not have to be this way. For example, Ontario Hydro recently diverted funds previously earmarked for nuclear energy into energy efficiency and conservation, an example that this government would do very well to follow.
So what can be done? How can we better use the public resources that are available to effect a goal that we all claim to desire, which is far greater efficiency in the use of energy in Canada and far more integration of the energy alternatives that are available into our civil society?
There are literally countless ways in which the federal government could spur energy efficiency in Canada, but judging from the thin gruel of legislative activity in this area, this bill included, increasing energy efficiency is clearly not a top priority with the current government. Still, in a spirit of non-partisan accommodation, let me give to the government, which has become virtually invisible, a series of suggestions.
First, implement compulsory fuel efficiency standards for new cars, vans and trucks by at long last proclaiming the Motor Vehicle Consumption Standards Act which was passed by this House in 1982 but to this day has not yet been proclaimed. Voluntary standards are not working. The over-all fuel efficiency of Canada's new motor vehicle fleet increased rapidly during the 1970s, but it slowed in the 1980s and has declined since 1988. We have not only stopped making headway, we are falling back. Adopting progressively more stringent fuel efficiency standards should be one element of a comprehensive Canadian strategy to develop a more energy efficient and environmentally friendly economy.
Environment Canada's inventory of C02 emissions, published in May 1990, estimates that Canadian road vehicles emitted nearly 27 million tonnes of C02 in 1987. The entire transportation sector emitted 39 million tonnes, roughly 30 per cent of Canada's total of 128 million tonnes. The National Energy Board projects the transportation sector will emit nearly 150 million tonnes of C02 by the year 2010.
Government Orders
The August 1989 report by federal, provincial and territorial energy ministers concluded that, and I quote:
Transportation energy use offers the greatest potential for emissions reductions at point of use.
"The greatest potential", Madam Speaker. What do we do knowing this? This is not a secret, this is not a surprise. Governments and their bureaucracies know this. What do we do? We continue to refuse to proclaim that act, already passed by this House, which would allow us to put in place the progressively more stringent new vehicle standards that would cause massive cuts in emissions.
It is inexplicable but it is a simple, easy place to start. I urge the government in the spirit of the bill it has placed before us today to proclaim that act as well.
Second, we can encourage the design and construction of energy efficient buildings. This is not hard to achieve. The government should start by strengthening the provisions of the 1983 measures for energy conservation in new buildings under the National Building Code. It should incorporate the strengthened measures into the code by extending those measures to include apartments and other commercial buildings not covered by provincial jurisdiction for which energy efficient guidelines do not now exist. At the same time, it can work with the provinces to effect similar improvements in the provincial building codes.
A third step is to restore funding of energy efficiency, conservation and energy alternatives to 1984 levels, especially for research, development and commercialization of new alternatives, for example, the Ballard hydrogen cell being developed in Vancouver. Mr. Ballard himself told the Standing Committee on Energy, Mines and Resources that he was in danger of losing control of his company that has developed this cell which is at least six months ahead of anything else on the planet, to a foreign owner because he cannot in Canada raise the measly $50 million he needs to pursue its commercialization.
If ever there was a place for government to involve itself in the aid both of a cleaner, healthier environment and in the aid of a developing Canadian industry on the

February 20, 1992
Government Orders
cutting edge of international technology, this is it. Or the development in Alberta of the solar pumps that can be used on farms to pump water out of the ground, strictly working on the basis of the sun that shines down out of the sky. This too represents tremendous potential both for domestic development and for international sales. Or, and this is so obvious, the massive extension of fuel ethanol availability throughout Canada.
There is at present one oil company in Canada, the independent Mohawk Oil Company in western Canada, that supplies ethanol blended fuels. There is no reason on God's good green earth why we could not make that a requirement for every gasoline vending corporation in this country. It would be good for the environment and Lord knows it would be good for the farmers who grow the grain and other crops from which the ethanol could be derived.
As well, a fourth step is to restore the conservation and renewable energy offices, the CREOs, across the country, so that Canadians have easy access to the information on the basis of which to make environmentally wise choices about energy and energy use.
In short, what is required is that the government abandon its so-called market based approach to energy policy. Instead let the government develop policies and programs emphasizing a strategic combination of energy efficiency standards, improved information programs, direct financial incentives and research, development, demonstration and commercialization so that Canada may begin to achieve the major economic and environmental benefits that energy efficiency, conservation and alternatives have to offer.
This bill is a step in the right direction. It is a baby step. It is a teensy little step, but it is a step. Even allowing that, we will have some significant questions in committee. We will be interested in expanding the scope of this bill to the extent that it is deemed to be in order. We will be interested in learning if there is any justification for the fact that the bill applies merely to energy using products, thereby apparently excluding significant products such as doors and windows. We will be asking why the bill applies only to manufacturers and bulk importers, thereby apparently allowing the import into Canada of energy inefficient appliances by individuals. These detailed matters will be pursued in committee.
Let me note in conclusion that while we support this bill and acknowledge that it is a teensy step in the right direction, we are also hoping the government will come forward soon with much more significant bills in this vein.
There is a great deal to be done. We in the New Democrat caucus applaud lightly this first step, but we urge the government to seize this matter and take those giant steps that are required. Let green gabled Anna with her chihuahua in her lap ponder her Bonsai rubber tree. Let the Canadian government on behalf of the Canadian people get to work on the job that needs to be done.

Madam Speaker, it was with great interest that I listened to my colleague speaking on the government bill.
Of course, we in the New Democratic Party support the concept of energy conservation. I would like my colleague to comment on this. Every time we see the government rely upon voluntary standards, particularly in the automobile industry, or every time the automobile industry comes up with their own standards, it seems that the average motorist gets it in the neck.
Or in the lungs.

Or in the lungs, or the pocketbook. I want to bring two points to the attention of my colleague that I would like him to comment on.
When we were looking at energy savings and at the same time reducing pollutants, particularly in 1976 as a result of the American efforts and the Canadian efforts just to be in conformity with the American efforts, there was a device called a catalytic converter that was attached to the internal combustion engine or the exhaust system. As consumer advocates we have always called it "the infernal combustion engine" because it is most inefficient.
This catalytic converter was supposed to clean up the pollutants as well as make for a cleaner running, smoother engine. I have to say that this has not occurred. We were told that we would only need a tune-up maybe once every year because the engines would run much cleaner. We were told that we would save on fuel. For the first five years, of course, we did not save.
February 20, 1992

Finally, if I may just conclude, motorists felt that they were being had by the industry in the name of protecting the environment.
I would appreciate my colleague's comments on this.

Madam Speaker, I must say that in matters involving automobiles and the automotive industry I bow to the expertise of my colleague from Chambly. Lord knows he is probably the best known consumer advocate, vis-a-vis the automobile industry in the country, perhaps on the continent. When he tells me that catalytic converters have been a bad thing, I am not going to argue. In fact, this had been my suspicion, but I must confess that what the hon. member has said now greatly reinforces that suspicion.
I would just repeat something I said in the body of my remarks earlier, which is that the record of government regulation of automobile emissions is clear. When those regulations were brought in and effected in the mid-1970s, emissions from automobiles dropped. In some regard, they plummeted. However, when those standards became voluntary in the early 1980s, progress virtually ceased.
People were spending time worrying even about those voluntary emissions. The people in the industry do not any more. Since 1988 we have fallen back. Emissions from automobiles have grown worse.
I can think of no clearer example of the efficacy of government regulation. It may be distasteful for those who believe in the market red in tooth and claw to contemplate the prospect of the public sector telling market players what they can or cannot do. As unpleasant as that prospect may be, it is absolutely essential if as a society we are to progress. That clearly is the record of the history of this country and indeed of all countries, and to argue against it is mere cavilling of the most captious sort.
I thank the hon. member for his comment. I thank the hon. member for his instruction. I wish him all the best in continuing to defend Canadian motorists.

Madam Speaker, it gives me great pleasure to rise in the House today to speak on Bill C-41, the energy efficiency and alternative energy act. I
Government Orders
have more than a passing interest in this piece of legislation since I have had a private member's bill on the books for over two years that has practically the same things in it, almost word for word. At the outset I want to offer my hearty congratulations to the government for following the strong, progressive and capable lead of the Liberal Party of Canada.
My Bill C-347, the energy conservation standards act, has the same provisions about setting minimum energy efficiency standards on equipment and requiring special labelling to show consumers the most efficient products. My bill also called for national standards that are consistent across the country. So does Bill C-41.
I must say again that I am glad the Tory government is finally taking this initiative. It is a long time in coming, and this is from a government that had slashed alternative energy programs by over 90 per cent since 1984.
The current government is also following the lead of many provinces including Ontario where the Liberal government of the day introduced its own energy efficiency act in December 1987.1 guess it is better late than never for the members across the floor.
Saving energy by regulation is a tool of the government. We know that economies around the world operate at below the optimum level of energy efficiency. Ontario and the rest of Canada are no exception. Energy efficiency provides a stream of economic and environmental benefits.
We all realize the barriers that prevent these sorts of energy savings from being captured. These barriers include a lack of consumer information and rate structures that may act as disincentives to conservation.
These barriers must be broken down. Governments have powerful tools to remove them, such as their fiscal policy to favour conservation, leadership by example- that is a good one for this government-incentive programs, consumer education, support for research and development, and actual regulation of minimum energy efficiency levels.
While on the one hand I applaud the government for coming through with this bill, I must also point out that one of the major concerns of people is the disgraceful neglect and declining level of support for Canada's alternative energy programs since 1984.

February 20, 1992
Government Orders
The development of new energy sources normally takes decades to accomplish. Research cannot be turned on and off from one fiscal year to the next without doing great harm to research efforts.
A recent study shows federal funding has been horribly slashed from about $500 million in 1984 to merely $30 million in 1990-91.1 certainly hope the finance minister will be more environmentally conscious in next Tuesday's budget.
It is worthy of note that during the period from 1980 to 1984 an average of $400 million was spent on alternative and energy conservation programs. Then in 1984 the Conservatives out and out eliminated the energy division of the National Research Council. There have been cuts at Energy, Mines and Resources for staff and branch offices, and programs to help people insulate their homes, to inform consumers about home appliances, and to advise industries on how to reduce energy consumption were all discarded. Perhaps Bill C-41 is a deathbed repentance for the Tories. Improving energy efficiency means reducing energy waste. Better building designs, more efficient equipment, improved furnaces, transportation and electric motors can lead to further significant gains. Energy efficiency is the leanest, cheapest and fastest way to improve the energy balance.
The House of Commons Standing Committee on Environment has made great progress on getting the four rs implemented on Parliament Hill. The hon. Speaker of the House has spearheaded these actions and he should be congratulated for the extremely successful greening of the Hill plans.
It cannot be overstated that energy efficiency is needed in Canada. A November 1990 study stated that among the industrialized countries Canada ranks first in energy use per capita, first in energy unit per Gross Domestic Product unit, and second in per capita carbon dioxide emissions.
In the early 1980s there was a tremendous improvement of about 10 per cent in CO2 emissions, but over the last five years there has been no reduction in energy intensity. This is mainly due to the current government's cutbacks in programs since 1984.
Performance on energy efficiency and carbon emissions since then has not only been a disgrace, but many-

Mr. Speaker, northern Ontario's forestry sector employs
37,000	people. Over 30 communities largely depend on this industry for their survival.
The pulp and paper industry in northern Ontario has been hard hit by the recession, by the high transportation costs in accessing and exporting its resources and by its high production costs due to antiquated equipment. In Ontario, 60 per cent of newsprint machines were installed before 1930.

February 20, 1992
If the pulp and paper industry is to survive it is absolutely essential for it to invest in new equipment and technology in order for it to become competitive in the global marketplace.
The Liberal Party made recommendations to the government last year asking it to consider implementing a proposal which would require industries to re invest 20 per cent of their annual profits into modernization and pollution control to ensure that they remain competitive.
We also suggested that the government look at implementing an industrial investment fund system of corporate RRSPs similar to the one being used in Sweden.
It is incumbent upon this government to take the leading role in ensuring that the pulp and paper industry in northern Ontario and across Canada becomes competitive through technological change.

Mr. Speaker, this government has again demonstrated that we are listening to the concerns of Canadian women by introducing new legislation that will make major improvements to public pensions.
Part-time employees may now join pension plans.
In the future, plans must offer survivor benefits and these must continue after re-marriage.
Pensions and pension credits will be divided upon marriage break-down.
Men and women retiring under similar circumstances will be entitled to equal pensions.
This will greatly help those who need retirement protection the most. It will help Canadian women.

Mr. Speaker, British Columbia's largest forest company, MacMillan Bloedel, lost $90 million in 1991.
During the same year MacMillan Bloedel blamed continuing losses for the closure of a plywood mill and a
sawmill operation in Port Alberni. These closures permanently disrupted the lives of 600 families in my riding.
Within the last few weeks MacMillan Bloedel issued indefinite lay-off notices to over 450 loggers in three coastal logging divisions. Corporate losses were blamed for these lay-offs as well.
Yet a few weeks ago, in spite of its 1991 losses and in spite of lay-off notices given to over 1,000 of its workers, MacMillan Bloedel declared a quarterly dividend of 15 cents per share on its 100 million outstanding common share.
There should be a law in this country that prevents well-heeled corporate boards from plundering a company's assets to pay themselves dividends while putting workers out on the streets and blaming corporate losses for the lay-offs.
