GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, since the GATT negotiations began, the Canadian government has always had only one position: to clarify and strengthen article XI.
I would like to assure the farmers in my riding that the government will continue to work hard towards that goal, witness its latest initiative, sending to Brussels a Canadian delegation headed by our ministers and with representatives of the farming community.
Nor could we overlook the work done by the Prime Minister, who is striving to resolve the issue in our favour.
Certain recent statements and accusations made against the government by the president of the UPA, Jacques Proulx, and the leader of the Bloc Quebecois, Lucien Bouchard, were an attempt to distort the situation in the interests of another quite different cause.
I would ask people to refer to the editorial by Alain Dubuc in today's La Presse. It shows very clearly what those two are up to. Obviously they are not serving the cause of Quebec farmers.
February 20, 1992

Again I want to assure the farmers in my riding of Joliette that the federal government will continue to defend their interests, as it has always done in the past.

Mr. Speaker, when the Minister of Finance presents his budget to Canadians next TUesday, I urge him to remove the excise tax on ethanol used in transportation fuel.
We also call on the government to adopt a comprehensive policy to promote the use of ethanol blended gasolines. If all our transportation fuel in Canada had a 10 per cent ethanol blend, we would create new markets for Canadian grain farmers of 8 million tonnes a year, larger than any one of our international markets today.
If all gasoline in Canada had a 10 per cent blend of ethanol we would reduce carbon dioxide emissions from automobiles by 10 per cent. That is why ethanol blended gasoline is often called green gas.
The use of ethanol blended gasoline would conserve our non-renewable resources.
By 1995 we will be importing over 550,000 barrels of crude oil a day from abroad. Ethanol is a winner for farmers, for conservation and the environment, for industrial development and for all of Canada.
We call on the Minister of Finance to remove the excise tax on ethanol blended gasolines next TUesday.

Mr. Speaker, although we must admit the obvious fact that everyone has to help the economic recovery along, some people are unfairly treated by the tax system on the basis of their marital status. Among them, Mr. Speaker, are married people with children, whose situation compared to unmarried people with children is particularly remarkable.
Indeed, under our present tax system a married couple with three children is at a clear disadvantage compared to an unmarried couple in the same situation and with the same number of children. This discrimination, on the
basis of marital status alone, costs married individuals up to $3,000.
That is totally unacceptable and I think it is ridiculous that couples are penalized just for being married. The Progressive Conservative caucus and I have made many representations about this to the Minister of Finance.
Hopefully next Tuesday's budget will bring concrete measures to improve this situation, for the greater good of Canadian families.

Mr. Speaker, six children were buried yesterday in the frozen ground of the Innu community of Davis Inlet, a small Indian village on the north coast of Labrador.
They died tragically in a fire while their parents were out drinking. This is not the first alcohol related death in Davis Inlet. But alcohol is simply a symptom of a more profound malaise that has at its roots a sense of powerlessness and lack of control over one's own life.
The Innu live in substandard housing with no insulation, no water and sewers, and at a distance from the caribou on which their way of life depends.
The Innu nation believes a full inquiry is needed to determine the underlying causes of the recurrence of tragedy at Davis Inlet.
At the same time, they have asked the minister of Indian affairs to act immediately to provide an adequate water supply, proper housing and necessary services for the community.
I strongly support these requests on behalf of the Innu nation. I call upon the minister of Indian affairs to act quickly so as to prevent further tragedy such as that experienced this week in Davis Inlet.

Mr. Speaker, no one, either here in the House of Commons or elsewhere in Canada if they have been concerning themselves with the future of our great country will deny that we are facing a serious crisis.

February 20,1992
The Minister responsible for Constitutional Affairs was asked by the Prime Minister to lead and co-ordinate our efforts to unite Canada.
I believe that Canadians everywhere, including those of us living in Quebec, are growing in our appreciation for his tireless efforts.
In an extensive interview for, but not used by the CBC on The Journal last night, the minister reported on the efforts being made.
The part of the interview with the minister that was broadcast raised the "what if" question: What would happen to Canadian citizens in Quebec if Quebec voted in a referendum to become a sovereign state?
I have talked with the minister and I am assured that the Government of Canada will preserve and protect the interests of all Canadians living in Quebec, primarily by bringing Canada together in a new Constitution including Quebec, even if we cannot persuade Quebecers that Canada belongs to all of us and is stronger when it is united and shared.
It is unfortunate that the full interview with the minister was not broadcast by The Journal.

Mr. Speaker, it is now February 20 and there has still been no announcement of this year's Challenge program for our student summer jobs.
But there have been plenty of other announcements: at least $350 million cut from the Canadian Jobs Strategy, increased tuitions resulting from the government's $11 billion cut in transfers for post-secondary education to the provinces, and continued stonewalling on revisions to the Canada Student Loans program.
Last summer young people were battered by the recession suffering unemployment rates 68 per cent higher than the year before and 65 per cent higher than the rest of the population.
Students have to wonder why has the Challenge program funding not been announced. Is the news so bad
that this government hopes to sneak it past us in a budget full of even worse news, in a budget that misses the point, that the competitive economy must really be the opportunity economy?

Mr. Speaker, it is with pleasure that I draw the attention of this House to another medal winning performance by a Canadian athlete in Albertville.
Our congratulations go to Myriam Bedard of Neufcha-tel, Quebec, who won a bronze medal in the women's 15 kilometre biathlon event.
This biathlon became a medal event for the first time in this Olympics. It is a sport which requires a combination of skills. Speed, stamina and endurance are needed on the 15 kilometre cross-country ski course and accuracy and skill with a rifle are needed on the target range.
Myriam demonstrated both the brilliant technical skill and the endurance demanded by this incredibly challenging sport.
I know that all Canadians will take pride and joy in her Olympic achievement which serves as an inspiration to all Canadian athletes.

Instead of turning his mind and heart to the merits of this case, to what is fair and just, the minister spends four pages implying that this family circumvented the process, did not follow the rules, are seeking special exemption and are abusing the system. If there is any abuse of the system it is in the minister's office and in the minister's department: delays of three years in holding hearings, no reply to a member of Parliament on behalf of her constituents, no reply even today to what are the criteria and how were they judged.

pray to God he will stop this deportation hearing this afternoon and will have the courtesy of giving me a reply to those concerns.

Mr. Speaker, I take this opportunity to remind members of the House and all Canadians that February is Heart Month.
Cardiovascular diseases are the main cause of disability and death in Canada. Seventy thousand people die from the disease each year.
In collaboration with provincial ministries of health, the Department of National Health and Welfare has established the Canadian Heart Health Initiative consisting of cardiovascular risk factor surveys and demonstration projects carried out in all provinces.
In addition, an international Heart Health Conference will be held in Victoria, British Columbia on May 24 to 28, 1992. The theme of the conference is "Bridging the Gap-Science and Policy in Action". I would like to applaud the efforts of all of those who are collaborating with the Department of National Health and Welfare toward reducing the burden of cardiovascular disease on Canadians. Let us work together to ensure the health of all Canadians. Let us work together for a better Canada.

February 20, 1992

Mr. Speaker, 1992 marks the 100th anniversary of the publication of the Principles and Practise of Medicine by a great Canadian, Sir William Osier. This medical text book, first published in 1892, remained in print with revisions every three years until the 16th edition in 1947.
Sir William Osier, bom in Bondhead, Ontario in 1849, remains the ideal of every physician in the English speaking world and beyond. He taught in Canada, the U.S. and Britain that education is a lifetime occupation and that hard work is essential.
Dr. Osier was one of the original four professors invited to begin the John Hopkins Medical School in Baltimore. He combined intelligence, knowledge and a love for study and teaching that continues to set a standard for all physicians. The Government of Canada issued a stamp in his honour in 1969.
Protecting and preserving Canada's heritage means recognizing the contributions our citizens have made, both within and outside this country. Let us not forget Sir William Osier.

The government tells us that the Europeans are arrogant, that they are stubborn, that they have ignored the pleadings of him and his government over the last
two years. Yet the government tells us that it intends to do more of the same. I ask him why? More to the point, I ask him when is he going to get involved as Prime Minister and turn the heat up on this file?

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Prime Minister.

I have to say to the Prime Minister that this is another torpedo to consumer confidence in this country. My question is this.
Informetrica has shown that a 2 per cent drop in Canadian interest rates would get us 52,000 extra jobs and over $4 billion in savings on the deficit. Will the government change policy, reduce interest rates and thereby expand jobs here in this country?

Mr. Speaker, I think my friend perhaps forget to mention that interest rates have come down some seven and a half points since their high in April 1990.
Interest rates are down to lows that have not been seen in almost 20 years in Canada. The inflation rate is in the process of annualizing very substantially at under 3 per cent, which compares, for example, to a high of 12.9 per cent that went on for some time in the early 1980s.
I think my hon. friend would recognize and acknowledge that this means very substantial progress. There has been a slight upward move of 10 basis points today, but there has been no reflection yet in terms of the prime. We will have to see what happens.
In any event, my hon. friend will surely agree that the only way there can be solid job creation is by keeping inflation low, keeping interest rates down and by inviting investment, both national and foreign, to join in Canada for the creation of the kinds of stimulating jobs that Canadians need.

Mr. Speaker, in fact, if we go back two months ago, the gap between Canada's interest rate for treasury bills and those in the United States was just over 2 percentage points.
If we look at the situation now, the gap is 3.5 percentage points. Canada's interest rates for treasury bills are almost double those of the United States. That cannot make sense with our most close and toughest competitor. It shows up in the export figures that have come out today showing yet another collapse in export figures to the United States. In fact, for the past year exports to the United States have been down 2 per cent.
I want to ask the Prime Minister this: With all of his strong support for the free trade deal in the past, how can he say that the free trade deal is helping us when we are seeing our exports to the United States this past year down by 2 percentage points? Is it not time to raise the question of reducing our dollar so as to get the competitiveness that we need?
Mr. Speaker, my hon. friend must have asked about a half dozen questions in that very lengthy statement.

Take your time.
February 20, 1992

Well, I will take my time.
With regard to his opening comments about a relative decline in exports, he is only half right. There was a relative decline in imports as well from the United States because of the recession. We continue to have a very favourable and impressive balance of some $6 billion or $7 billion in terms of trade, so that part of it is readily disposed of.
With regard to the question of the Canadian dollar, my hon. friend surely must know that that is a determination made by the international marketplace in regard to fundamental criteria like low inflation rates, low unit costs, enhanced productivity. This all finds a reflection in the value of the Canadian dollar. In point of fact, it has come down by some 4.5 or 5 cents over the last two or two and a half months maximum. I think that probably finds favour with my hon. friend as well.
With regard to his final point where he invoked the free trade agreement, I would just point out to him that recently one of Canada's most distinguished economists, Ed Neufeld, the executive vice-president at the Royal Bank, and I think generally highly regarded, was asked the question: "Now they feel if you open up your borders in terms of trade, trading borders into Mexico, all it will mean for Canada is location of plants into Mexico and out of Canada". His response was: "Of course, that was the theory in Europe when they said, well, if you do this French plants will go to Greece or to Portugal. The point is it is not happening. It is not happening because free trade provides new opportunities in all countries that are party to that free trade". Mr. Neufeld concludes that: "In regard to understanding of the impacts and the liberalizing instincts of international trade, the only problem with Canada is that we were about 10 or 15 years behind and we are now catching up".

Mr. Speaker, in fact this government has defended the free trade deal on the basis of export increases to the United States. The figures are now out for last year. They show a decrease in those exports to the United States.
I want to ask the Prime Minister: What will his government do to reverse this situation? What will his government do to increase our exports by reducing the value of the dollar so Canadians can be competitive and give us jobs right across this country?

Mr. Speaker, my hon. friend's statement is quite wrong.
Oral Questions
Since the free trade agreement and irrespective of the fact that this country and the United States have fallen into a very difficult recession from which we are now in the process of recovering, the fact of the matter is that for the first time since I believe 1976 there is a net positive inflow of investment capital into Canada to the extent of some $8 billion or $9 billion over that same period.
Trade with the United States, which accounts for some 2 million jobs in Canada and 80 per cent of our exports, has increased since the free trade agreement has come in. More jobs have been created. In point of fact, fewer jobs have been lost in this recession with the free trade agreement than in 1981 and 1982 when there was no free trade agreement with the United States. So the free trade agreement, like the auto pact, will be viewed by Canadians as a most important instrument for a durable economic recovery.

My hon. friend has raised a very serious question, asking if we are acquainted with the difficulties. Indeed, we are. All members of the House are acquainted with the importance of this matter for the farmers.
I raised this question beginning at the Tokyo summit in 1986, right up until again in November in Paris at a three and half hour meeting with President Delors of the commission, yesterday in conversations with Prime Minister Major and again with Chancellor Kohl this morning, trying to cause them to understand the article XI implications which, for example, they have in respect of sugar in the common market and the impact this has upon Canadians in an entirely different way-a large country with a small population trying to maintain supply managed industries-because these do not involve international trade distorting subsidies.
The dairy farm in Canada, as it is elsewhere, but particularly in Canada is part of the national fibre of the nation.
I met with farm leaders privately on Tuesday. I met with farm leaders Tbesday afternoon publicly. I met earlier today with farm leaders from Manitoba here in the House of Commons. I have been speaking to world leaders about their problems.
At the moment we have the Minister for International Trade, the Minister of Agriculture and the Minister of State for Agriculture in Brussels en route to Bonn, after a very successful day in Brussels, advancing the cause of Canadian farmers.
These are perhaps not miracles, but I can tell my hon. friend that we are doing what she would want us to do, deploying every effort we humanly can, and to work day and night to protect the interests of Canadian farmers.

speechtext: Mr. Speaker, even for my hon. friend from the NDP this is a new height of speciousness. He makes a false statement.
